verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:1
verses.text: Homilies of St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:2
verses.text: John Chrysostom,  archbishop of constantinople,  on the  epistle to the hebrews  Published after his Falling Asleep, from Notes by Constantine, Presbyter of Antioch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:3
verses.text: Argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:4
verses.text: and Summary of the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:5
verses.text: The blessed Paul, writing to the Romans, says, "Inasmuch then as I am the Apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office: if by any means I may provoke to emulation them that are my flesh": and again, in another place, "For He that wrought effectually in Peter to the apostleship of the circumcision, the same was mighty in me toward the Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:6
verses.text: If therefore he were the Apostle of the Gentiles, (for also in the Acts, God said to him, "Depart; for I will send thee far hence unto the Gentiles,") what had he to do with the Hebrews? and why did he also write an Epistle to them?  And especially as besides, they were ill-disposed towards him, and this is to be seen from many places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:7
verses.text: For hear what James says to him, "Thou seest, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are which believe…and these all have been informed of thee that thou teachest men to forsake the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:8
verses.text: And oftentimes he had many disputings concerning this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:9
verses.text: Why therefore, one might ask, as he was so learned in the law (for he was instructed in the law at the feet of Gamaliel, and had great zeal in the matter, and was especially able to confound them in this respect)—why did not God send him to the Jews? Because on this very account they were more vehement in their enmity against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:10
verses.text: "For they will not endure thee," God says unto him; "But depart far hence to the Gentiles, for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:11
verses.text: Whereupon he says, "Yea, Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat in every synagogue them that believed on thee; and when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I also was standing by and consenting unto his death, and kept the raiment of them that slew him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:12
verses.text: And this he says is a sign and proof of their not believing him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:13
verses.text: For thus it is: when a man goes away from any people, if he be one of the least and of those who are nothing worth, he does not much vex those from whom he went; but if he be among the distinguished and earnest partisans and those who care for these things, he exceedingly grieves and vexes them beyond measure, in that he especially overthrows their system with the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:14
verses.text: And besides this, there was something else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:15
verses.text: What now might this be? That they who were about Peter were also with Christ, and saw signs and wonders; but he [Paul] having had the benefit of none of these, but being with Jews, suddenly deserted and became one of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:16
verses.text: This especially promoted our cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:17
verses.text: For while they indeed, seemed to testify even from gratitude, and one might have said that they bore witness to those things in love for their Master; he, on the other hand, who testifies to the resurrection, this man was rather one who heard a voice only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:18
verses.text: For this cause thou seest them waging war passionately with him, and doing all things for this purpose, that they might slay him, and raising seditions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:19
verses.text: The unbelievers, then, were hostile to him for this reason; but why were the believers? Because in preaching to the Gentiles he was constrained to preach Christianity purely; and if haply even in Judaea he were found [doing so], he cared not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:20
verses.text: For Peter and they that were with him, because they preached in Jerusalem, when there was great fierceness, of necessity enjoined the observance of the law; but this man was quite at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:21
verses.text: The [converts] too from the Gentiles were more than the Jews because they were without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:22
verses.text: And this enfeebled the law, and they had no such great reverence for it, although he preached all things purely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:23
verses.text: Doubtless in this matter they think to shame him by numbers, saying, "Thou seest, brother, how many ten thousands of Jews there are which are come together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:24
verses.text: On this account they hated him and turned away from him, because "They are informed of thee, he says, that thou teachest men to forsake the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:25
verses.text: Why, then, not being a teacher of the Jews, does he send an Epistle to them? And where were those to whom he sent it? It seems to me in Jerusalem and Palestine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:26
verses.text: How then does he send them an Epistle? Just as he baptized, though he was not commanded to baptize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:27
verses.text: For, he says, "I was not sent to baptize": not, however, that he was forbidden, but he does it as a subordinate matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:28
verses.text: And how could he fail to write to those, for whom he was willing even to become accursed? Accordingly he said, "Know ye that our brother Timothy is set at liberty; with whom, if he come shortly, I will see you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:29
verses.text: For as yet he was not arrested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:30
verses.text: Two years then he passed bound, in Rome; then he was set free; then, having gone into Spain, he saw Jews also in like manner; and then he returned to Rome, where also he was slain by Nero.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:31
verses.text: The Epistle to Timothy then was later than this Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:32
verses.text: For there he says, "For I am now ready to be offered" ; there also he says, "In my first answer no man stood with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:33
verses.text: In many places they [the Hebrew Christians] had to contend with persecution, as also he says, writing to the Thessalonians, "Ye became followers of the churches of Judaea": and writing to these very persons he says, "Ye took joyfully the spoiling of your goods".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:34
verses.text: Dost thou see them contending? And if men had thus treated the Apostles, not only in Judaea, but also wherever they were among the Gentiles, what would they not have done to the believers? On this account, thou seest, he was very careful for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:35
verses.text: For when he says, "I go unto Jerusalem to minister unto the saints"; and again, when he exhorts the Corinthians to beneficence, and says that the Macedonians had already made their contribution, and says, "If it be meet that I go also," —he means this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:36
verses.text: And when he says, "Only that we should remember the poor; the same which I also was forward to do," —he declares this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:37
verses.text: And when he says, "They gave to me and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship; that we should go unto the heathen, and they unto the circumcision," —he declares this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:38
verses.text: But this was not for the sake of the poor who were there, but that by this we might be partakers in the beneficence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:39
verses.text: For not as the preaching did we apportion the care for the poor to each other (we indeed to the Gentiles, but they to the circumcision).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:40
verses.text: And everywhere thou seest him using great care for them: as was reasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:41
verses.text: Among the other nations indeed, when there were both Jews and Greeks, such was not the case; but then, while they still seemed to have authority and independence and to order many things by their own laws, the government not being yet established nor brought perfectly under the Romans, they naturally exercised great tyranny.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:42
verses.text: For if in other cities, as in Corinth, they beat the Ruler of the synagogue before the Deputy's judgment seat, and Gallio "cared for none of these things," but it was not so in Judaea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:43
verses.text: Thou seest indeed, that while in other cities they bring them to the magistrates, and need help from them and from the Gentiles, here they took no thought of this, but assemble a Sanhedrim themselves and slay whom they please.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:44
verses.text: Thus in fact they put Stephen to death, thus they beat the Apostles, not taking them before rulers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:45
verses.text: Thus also they were about to put Paul to death, had not the chief captain thrown himself [upon them].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:46
verses.text: For this took place while the priests, while the temple, while the ritual, the sacrifices were yet standing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:47
verses.text: Look indeed at Paul himself being tried before the High Priest, and saying,"I wist not that he was the High Priest," and this in the presence of the Ruler.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:48
verses.text: For they had then great power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:49
verses.text: Consider then what things they were likely to suffer who dwelt in Jerusalem and Judaea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:50
verses.text: He then who prays to become accursed for those who were not yet believers, and who so ministers to the faithful, as to journey himself, if need be, and who everywhere took great care of them;—let us not wonder if he encourage and comfort them by letters also, and if he set them upright when tottering and fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:51
verses.text: For in a word, they were worn down and despairing on account of their manifold afflictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:52
verses.text: And this he shows near the end, saying, "Wherefore lift up the hands that hang down, and the feeble knees"; and again, "Yet a little while, he that shall come will come, and will not tarry"; and again, "If ye be without chastisement,…then are ye bastards and not sons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:53
verses.text: For since they were Jews and learned from the fathers that they must expect both their good and their evil immediately and must live accordingly, but then [when the Gospel came] the opposite was [taught]—their good things being in hope and after death, their evils in hand, though they had patiently endured much, it was likely that many would be fainthearted;—hereon he discourses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:54
verses.text: But we will unfold these things at a fit opportunity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:55
verses.text: At present: he of necessity wrote to those for whom he cared so greatly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:56
verses.text: For while the reason why he was not sent to them is plain, yet he was not forbidden to write.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:57
verses.text: And that they were becoming fainthearted he shows when he says, "Lift up the hands which hang down, and the feeble knees, and make straight paths" and again, "God is not unrighteous to forget your work and love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:58
verses.text: For the soul overtaken by many trials, was turned aside even from the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:59
verses.text: Therefore he exhorts them to "Give heed to the things which they have heard, and that there should not be an evil heart of unbelief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:60
verses.text: On this account also, in this Epistle, especially, he argues at length concerning faith, and after much [reasoning] shows at the end that to them [of old] also He promised good things in hand, and yet gave nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:61
verses.text: And besides these things, he establishes two points that they might not think themselves forsaken: the one, that they should bear nobly whatever befalls them; the other, that they should look assuredly for their recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:62
verses.text: For truly He will not overlook those with Abel and the line of unrewarded righteous following him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:63
verses.text: And he draws comfort in three ways: first, from the things which Christ suffered: as He Himself says, "The servant is not greater than his Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:64
verses.text: Next, from the good things laid up for the believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:65
verses.text: Thirdly, from the evils; and this point he enforces not only from the things to come (which would be less persuasive), but also from the past and from what had befallen their fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:66
verses.text: Christ also does the same, at one time saying, "The servant is not greater than his Lord"; and again, "There are many mansions with the Father"; and He denounces innumerable woes on the unbelievers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:67
verses.text: But he speaks much of both the New and the Old Covenant; for this was useful to him for the proof of the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:68
verses.text: Lest they should disbelieve that [Christ] rose on account of the things which He suffered, he confirms it from the Prophets, and shows that not the Jewish, but ours are the sacred [institutions].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:69
verses.text: For the temple yet stood and the sacrificial rites; therefore he says, "Let us go forth therefore without, bearing His reproach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:70
verses.text: But this also was made an argument against him: "If these things are a shadow, if these things are an image, how is it that they have not passed away or given place when the truth was manifested, but these things still flourish?" This also he quietly intimates shall happen, and that at a time close at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 1:71
verses.text: Moreover, he makes it plain that they had been a long time in the faith and in afflictions, saying, "When for the time ye ought to be teachers," and, "Lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief," and ye became "Followers of them who through patience inherit the promises".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:2
verses.text: Hebrews i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:3
verses.text: ,  "God who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the Prophets, hath at the end of the days spoken unto us by His Son whom He hath appointed heir of all things, by whom also He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:4
verses.text: Truly, "where sin abounded, grace did much more abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:5
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:6
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:7
verses.text: ) This at least the blessed Paul intimates here also, in the very beginning of his Epistle to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:8
verses.text: For since as it was likely that afflicted, worn out by evils, and judging of things thereby, they would think themselves worse off than all other men,—he shows that herein they had rather been made partakers of greater, even very exceeding, grace; arousing the hearer at the very opening of his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:9
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "God who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in times past unto the fathers by the Prophets, hath at the end of the days spoken unto us by His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:10
verses.text: Why did he [Paul] not oppose "himself" to "the prophets"? Certainly, he was much greater than they, inasmuch as a greater trust was committed to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:11
verses.text: Yet he doth not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:12
verses.text: Why? First, to avoid speaking great things concerning himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:13
verses.text: Secondly, because his hearers were not yet perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:14
verses.text: And thirdly, because he rather wished to exalt them, and to show that their superiority was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:15
verses.text: As if he had said, What so great matter is it that He sent prophets to our fathers? For to us [He has sent] His own only-begotten Son Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:16
verses.text: And well did he begin thus, "At sundry times and in divers manners," for he points out that not even the prophets themselves saw God; nevertheless, the Son saw Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:17
verses.text: For the expressions, "at sundry times and in divers manners" are the same as "in different ways".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:18
verses.text: "For I" (saith He) "have multiplied visions, and used similitudes by the ministry of the Prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:19
verses.text: ( Hos.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:20
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:21
verses.text: ) Wherefore the excellency consists not in this alone, that to them indeed prophets were sent, but to us the Son; but that none of them saw God, but the Only-begotten Son saw Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:22
verses.text: He doth not indeed at once assert this, but by what he says afterwards he establishes it, when he speaks concerning His human nature; "For to which of the Angels said He, Thou art My Son," ( ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:23
verses.text: ), and, "Sit thou on My right hand"? ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:24
verses.text: )  And look on his great wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:25
verses.text: First he shows the superiority from the prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:26
verses.text: Then having established this as acknowledged, he declares that to them indeed He spake by the prophets, but to us by the Only-begotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:27
verses.text: Then [He spake] to them by Angels, and this again he establishes, with good reason (for angels also held converse with the Jews): yet even herein we have the superiority, inasmuch as the Master [spake] to us, but to them servants, and prophets, fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:28
verses.text: Well also said he, "at the end of the days," for by this he both stirs them up and encourages them desponding of the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:29
verses.text: For as he says also in another place, "The Lord is at hand, be careful for nothing" ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:30
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:31
verses.text: ,  ), and again, "For now is our salvation nearer than when we believed" ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:32
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:33
verses.text: ): so also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:34
verses.text: What then is it which he says? That whoever is spent in the conflict, when he hears of the end thereof, recovers his breath a little, knowing that it is the end indeed of his labors, but the beginning of his rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:35
verses.text: "Hath in the end of the days spoken unto us in [His] Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:36
verses.text: Behold again he uses the saying, "in [His] Son," for "through the Son," against those who assert that this phrase is proper to the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:37
verses.text: Dost thou see that the [word] "in" is "through"?  And the expression, "In times past," and this, "In the end of the days," shadows forth some other meaning:—that when a long time had intervened, when we were on the edge of punishment, when the Gifts had failed, when there was no expectation of deliverance, when we were expecting to have less than all—then we have had more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:38
verses.text: And see how considerately he hath spoken it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:39
verses.text: For he said not, "Christ spake" (albeit it was He who did speak), but inasmuch as their souls were weak, and they were not yet able to hear the things concerning Christ, he says, "God hath spoken by Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:40
verses.text: What meanest thou? did God speak through the Son? Yes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:41
verses.text: What then? Is it thus thou showest the superiority? for here thou hast but pointed out that both the New and the Old [Covenants] are of One and the same: and that this superiority is not great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:42
verses.text: Wherefore he henceforth follows on upon this argument, saying, "He spake unto us by [His] Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:43
verses.text: (Note, how Paul makes common cause, and puts himself on a level with the disciples, saying, He spake "to us": and yet He did not speak to him, but to the Apostles, and through them to the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:44
verses.text: But he lifts them [the Hebrews] up, and declares that He spake also to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:45
verses.text: And as yet he doth not at all reflect on the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:46
verses.text: For almost all to whom the prophets spake, were a kind of evil and polluted persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:47
verses.text: But as yet the discourse is not of these: but, hitherto of the gifts derived from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:48
verses.text: )  "Whom He appointed," saith he, "heir of all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:49
verses.text: What is "whom He appointed heir of all"? He speaks here of the flesh [the human nature].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:50
verses.text: As He also says in the second Psalm, "Ask of Me, and I will give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:51
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:52
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:53
verses.text: ) For no longer is "Jacob the portion of the Lord" nor "Israel His inheritance" ( Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:54
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:55
verses.text: ), but all men: that is to say, He hath made Him Lord of all: which Peter also said in the Acts, "God hath made Him both Lord and Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:56
verses.text: ( Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:57
verses.text: ) But he has used the name "Heir," declaring two things: His proper sonship and His indefeasible sovereignty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:58
verses.text: "Heir of all," that is, of all the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:59
verses.text: Then again he brings back his discourse to its former point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:60
verses.text: "By whom also He made the worlds [the ages]".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:61
verses.text: Where are those who say, There was [a time] when He was not?  Then, using degrees of ascent, he uttered that which is far greater than all this, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:63
verses.text: "Who, (being the brightness of His glory, and the express image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power,) when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high; being made so much better than the Angels as He hath by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:64
verses.text: O! the wisdom of the Apostle! or rather, not the wisdom of Paul, but the grace of the Spirit is the thing to wonder at.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:65
verses.text: For surely he uttered not these things of his own mind, nor in that way did he find his wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:66
verses.text: (For whence could it be? From the knife, and the skins, or the workshop?) But it was from the working of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:67
verses.text: For his own understanding did not give birth to these thoughts, which was then so mean and slender as in nowise to surpass the baser sort; (for how could it, seeing it spent itself wholly on bargains and skins?) but the grace of the Spirit shows forth its strength by whomsoever it will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:68
verses.text: For just as one, wishing to lead up a little child to some lofty place, reaching up even to the top of Heaven, does this gently and by degrees, leading him upwards by the steps from below,—then when he has set him on high, and bidden him to gaze downwards, and sees him turning giddy and confused, and dizzy, taking hold of him, he leads him down to the lower stand, allowing him to take breath; then when he hath recovered it, leads him up again, and again brings him down;—just so did the blessed Paul likewise, both with the Hebrews and everywhere, having learnt it from his Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:69
verses.text: For even He also did so; sometimes He led His hearers up on high, and sometimes He brought them down, not allowing them to remain very long.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:70
verses.text: See him, then, even here—by how many steps he led them up, and placed them near the very summit of religion, and then or ever they grow giddy, and are seized with dizziness, how he leads them again lower down, and allowing them to take breath, says, "He spake unto us by [His] Son," "whom He appointed Heir of all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:71
verses.text: For the name of Son is so far common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:72
verses.text: For where a true [Son] it is understood of, He is above all: but however that may be, for the present he proves that He is from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:73
verses.text: And see how he says it: "Whom He appointed," saith he, "heir of all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:74
verses.text: The phrase, "He appointed Heir," is humble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:75
verses.text: Then he placed them on the higher step, adding, "by whom also He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:76
verses.text: Then on a higher still, and after which there is no other, "who being the brightness of His glory, and the express image of His person".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:77
verses.text: Truly he has led them to unapproachable light, to the very brightness itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:78
verses.text: And before they are blinded see how he gently leads them down again, saying, "and upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:79
verses.text: He does not simply say, "He sat down," but "after the purifying, He sat down," for he hath touched on the Incarnation, and his utterance is again lowly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:80
verses.text: Then again having said a little by the way (for he says, "on the right hand of the Majesty on high"), [he turns] again to what is lowly; "being made so much better than the angels, as He hath by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:81
verses.text: Henceforward then he treats here of that which is according to the flesh, since the phrase "being made better" doth not express His essence according to the Spirit,  (for that was not "made" but "begotten,") but according to the flesh: for this was "made".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:82
verses.text: Nevertheless the discourse here is not about being called into existence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:83
verses.text: But just as John says, "He that cometh after me, is preferred before me" ( John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:84
verses.text: ,  ), that is, higher in honor and esteem; so also here, "being made so much better than the angels"—that is, higher in esteem and better and more glorious, "by how much He hath obtained by inheritance a more excellent name than they".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:85
verses.text: Seest thou that he is speaking of that which is according to the flesh? For this Name,  God the Word ever had; He did not afterwards "obtain it by inheritance"; nor did He afterwards become "better than the Angels, when He had purged our sins"; but He was always "better," and better without all comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:86
verses.text: For this is spoken of Him according to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:87
verses.text: So truly it is our way also, when we talk of man, to speak things both high and low.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:88
verses.text: Thus, when we say, "Man is nothing," "Man is earth," "Man is ashes," we call the whole by the worse part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:89
verses.text: But when we say, "Man is an immortal animal," and "Man is rational, and of kin to those on high," we call again the whole by the better part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:90
verses.text: So also, in the case of Christ, sometimes Paul discourseth from the less and sometimes from the better; wishing both to establish the economy, and also to teach about the incorruptible nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:91
verses.text: Since then "He hath purged our sins," let us continue pure; and let us receive no stain, but preserve the beauty which He hath implanted in us, and His comeliness undefiled and pure, "not having spot or wrinkle or any such thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:92
verses.text: ( Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:93
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:94
verses.text: ) Even little sins are "a spot and a wrinkle," such a thing, I mean, as Reproach, Insult, Falsehood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:95
verses.text: Nay, rather not even are these small, but on the contrary very great: yea so great as to deprive a man even of the kingdom of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:96
verses.text: How, and in what manner? "He that calleth his brother fool, is in danger" (He saith) "of hellfire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:97
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:98
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:99
verses.text: ) But if it be so with him who calls a man "fool," which seems to be the slightest of all things, and rather mere children's talk; what sentence of punishment will not he incur, who calleth him malignant and crafty and envious, and casteth at him ten thousand other reproaches? What more fearful than this?  Now suffer, I beseech you, the word [of exhortation].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:100
verses.text: For if he that "doeth" [aught] to "one of the least, doeth it to Him" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:101
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:102
verses.text: ), and he that "doeth it not to one of the least doeth it not to Him" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:103
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:104
verses.text: ), how is it not the same also in the matter of good or evil speaking? He that reviles his brother, reviles God: and he that honors his brother, honors God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:105
verses.text: Let us train therefore our tongue to speak good words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:106
verses.text: For "refrain," it is said, "thy tongue from evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:107
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:108
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:109
verses.text: ) For God gave it not that we should speak evil, that we should revile, that we should calumniate one another; but to sing hymns to God withal, to speak those things which "give grace to the hearers" ( Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:110
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:111
verses.text: ), things for edification, things for profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:112
verses.text: Hast thou spoken evil of a man? What is thy gain, entangling thyself in mischief together with him? For thou hast obtained the reputation of a slanderer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:113
verses.text: For there is not any, no not any evil, which stops at him that suffers it, but it includes the doer also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:114
verses.text: As for instance, the envious person seems indeed to plot against another, but himself first reaps the fruit of his sin, wasting and wearing himself away, and being hated of all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:115
verses.text: The cheat deprives another of his money; yea and himself too of men's good will: and causes himself to be evil spoken of by all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:116
verses.text: Now reputation is much better than money, for the one it is not easy to wash out, whereas it is easy to gain possession of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:117
verses.text: Or rather, the absence of the one doth no hurt to him that wanteth it; but the absence of the other makes you reproached and ridiculed, and an object of enmity and warfare to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:118
verses.text: The passionate man again first punishes and tears himself in pieces, and then him with whom he is angry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:119
verses.text: Just so the evil speaker disgraces first himself and then him who is evil-spoken of: or, it may be, even this hath proved beyond his power, and while he departs with the credit of a foul and detestable kind of person, he causes the other to be loved the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:120
verses.text: For when a man hearing a bad name given him, doth not requite the giver in the same kind, but praises and admires, he doth not praise the other, but himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:121
verses.text: For I before observed that, as calumnies against our neighbors first touch those who de vise the mischief, so also good works done towards our neighbors, gladden first those who do them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:122
verses.text: The parent either of good, or evil, justly reaps the fruit of it first himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:123
verses.text: And just as water, whether it be brackish or sweet, fills the vessels of those who resort to it, but lessens not the fountain which sends it forth; so surely also, both wickedness and virtue, from whatever person they proceed, prove either his joy or his ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:124
verses.text: So far as to the things of this world; but what speech may recount the things of that world, either the goods or the evils? There is none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:125
verses.text: For as to the blessings, they surpass all thought, not speech only; for their opposites are expressed indeed in terms familiar to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:126
verses.text: For fire, it is said, is there, and darkness, and bonds, and a worm that never dieth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:127
verses.text: But this represents not only the things which are spoken of, but others more intolerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:128
verses.text: And to convince thee, consider at once this first: if it be fire, how is it also darkness? Seest thou how that fire is more intolerable than this? For it hath no light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:129
verses.text: If it be fire, how is it forever burning? Seest thou how something more intolerable than this happens? For it is not quenched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:130
verses.text: Yea, therefore it is called unquenchable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:131
verses.text: Let us then consider how great a misery it must be, to be forever burning, and to be in darkness, and to utter unnumbered groanings, and to gnash the teeth, and not even to be heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:132
verses.text: For if here any one of those ingeniously brought up, should he be cast into prison, speaks of the mere ill savor, and the being laid in darkness, and the being bound with murderers, as more intolerable than any death: think what it is when we are burning with the murderers of the whole world, neither seeing nor being seen, but in so vast a multitude thinking that we are alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:133
verses.text: For the darkness and gloom doth not allow our distinguishing those who are near to us, but each will burn as if he were thus suffering alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:134
verses.text: Moreover, if darkness of itself afflicteth and terrifieth our souls, how then will it be when together with the darkness there are likewise so great pains and burnings?  Wherefore I entreat you to be ever revolving these things with yourselves, and to submit to the pain of the words, that we may not undergo the punishment of the things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:135
verses.text: For assuredly, all these things shall be, and those whose doings have deserved those chambers of torture no man shall rescue, not father, nor mother, nor brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:136
verses.text: "For a brother redeemeth not," He saith; "shall a man redeem?" ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:137
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:138
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:139
verses.text: ), though he have much confidence, though he have great power with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:140
verses.text: For it is He Himself who rewards every one according to his works, and upon these depends our salvation or punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:141
verses.text: Let us make then to ourselves "friends of the mammon of unrighteousness" ( Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:142
verses.text: ), that is: Let us give alms; let us exhaust our possessions upon them, that so we may exhaust that fire: that we may quench it, that we may have boldness there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:143
verses.text: For there also it is not they who receive us, but our own work: for that it is not simply their being our friends which can save us, learn from what is added.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:144
verses.text: For why did He not say, "Make to yourselves friends, that they may receive you into their everlasting habitations," but added also the manner? For saying, "of the mammon of unrighteousness," He points out that we must make friends of them by means of our possessions, showing that mere friendship will not protect us, unless we have good works, unless we spend righteously the wealth unrighteously gathered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:145
verses.text: Moreover, this our discourse, of Almsgiving I mean, fits not only the rich, but also the needy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:146
verses.text: Yea even if there be any person who supporteth himself by begging, even for him is this word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:147
verses.text: For there is no one, so poverty-stricken, however exceeding poor he may be, as not to be able to provide "two mites".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:148
verses.text: ( Luke xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:149
verses.text: ) It is therefore possible that a person giving a small sum from small means, should surpass those who have large possessions and give more; as that widow did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:150
verses.text: For not by the measure of what is given, but by the means and willingness of the givers is the extent of the alms-deed estimated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:151
verses.text: In all cases the will is needed, in all, a right disposition; in all, love towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:152
verses.text: If with this we do all things, though having little we give little, God will not turn away His face, but will receive it as great and admirable: for He regards the will, not the gifts: and if He see that to be great, He assigneth His decrees and judges accordingly, and maketh them partakers of His everlasting benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 2:153
verses.text: Which may God grant us all to obtain, by the grace and love of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:2
verses.text: Hebrews i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:3
verses.text: "Who being the brightness of His Glory and the express Image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power, when He had by Himself purged our sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:4
verses.text: Everywhere indeed a reverential mind is requisite, but especially when we say or hear anything of God: Since neither can tongue speak nor thought hear anything suitable to our God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:5
verses.text: And why speak I of tongue or thought? For not even the understanding which far excels these, will be able to comprehend anything accurately, when we desire to utter aught concerning God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:6
verses.text: For if "the peace of God surpasseth all understanding" ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:7
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:8
verses.text: ), and "the things which are prepared for them that love Him have not entered into the heart of man" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:9
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:10
verses.text: ); much more He Himself, the God of peace, the Creator of all things, doth by a wide measure exceed our reasoning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:11
verses.text: We ought therefore to receive all things with faith and reverence, and when our discourse fails through weakness, and is not able to set forth accurately the things which are spoken, then especially to glorify God, for that we have such a God, surpassing both our thought and our conception.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:12
verses.text: For many of our conceptions about God, we are unable to express, as also many things we express, but have not strength to conceive of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:13
verses.text: As for instance:—That God is everywhere, we know; but how, we no longer understand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:14
verses.text: That there is a certain incorporeal power the cause of all our good things, we know: but how it is, or what it is, we know not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:15
verses.text: Lo! we speak, and do not understand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:16
verses.text: I said, That He is everywhere, but I do not understand it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:17
verses.text: I said, That He is without beginning, but I do not understand it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:18
verses.text: I said, That He begat from Himself, and again I know not how I shall understand it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:19
verses.text: And some things there are which we may not even speak—as for instance, thought conceives  but cannot utter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:20
verses.text: And to show thee that even Paul is weak and doth not put out his illustrations with exactness; and to make thee tremble and refrain from searching too far, hear what he says, having called Him Son and named Him Creator, "Who being the brightness of His Glory, and the express image of His person".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:21
verses.text: This we must receive with reverence and clear of all incongruities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:22
verses.text: "The brightness of His glory," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:23
verses.text: But observe in what reference he understands this, and so do thou receive it:—that He is of Him: without passion: that He is neither greater, nor less; since there are some, who derive certain strange things from the illustration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:24
verses.text: For, say they, "the brightness" is not substantial, but hath its being in another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:25
verses.text: Now do not thou, O man, so receive it, neither be thou sick of the disease of Marcellus and Photinus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:26
verses.text: For he hath a remedy for thee close at hand, that thou fall not into that imagination, nor doth he leave thee to be hurried down into that fatal malady.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:27
verses.text: And what saith he? "And the express image of His person" [or "subsistence"]: that is, just as He [the Father] is personally subsisting, being in need of nothing, so also the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:28
verses.text: For he saith this here, showing the undeviating similitude and the peculiar image of the Prototype, that He [the Son] is in subsistence by Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:29
verses.text: For he who said above, that "by Him He made all things" here assigns to Him absolute authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:30
verses.text: For what doth he add? "And upholding all things by the word of His power"; that we might hence infer not merely His being the express image of His Person, but also His governing all things with absolute authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:31
verses.text: See then, how he applies to the Son that which is proper to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:32
verses.text: For on this account he did not say simply, "and upholding all things," nor did he say, "by His power," but, "by the word of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:33
verses.text: For much as just now we saw him gradually ascend and descend; so also now, as by steps, he goes up on high, then again descends, and saith, "by whom also He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:34
verses.text: Behold how here also he goes on two paths, by the one leading us away from Sabellius, by the other from Arius, yea and on another, that He [Christ] should not be accounted un originated, which he does also throughout, nor yet alien from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:35
verses.text: For if, even after so much, there are some who assert that He is alien, and assign to Him another father, and say that He is at variance with Him;—had [Paul] not declared these things, what would they not have uttered?  How then does he this? When he is compelled to heal, then is he compelled also to utter lowly things: as for instance, "He appointed Him" (saith he) "heir of all things," and "by Him He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:36
verses.text: (Supra, ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:37
verses.text: ) But that He might not be in another way dishonored, he brings Him up again to absolute authority and declares Him to be of equal honor with the Father, yea, so equal, that many thought Him to be the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:38
verses.text: And observe thou his great wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:39
verses.text: First he lays down the former point and makes it sure accurately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:40
verses.text: And when this is shown, that He is the Son of God, and not alien from Him, he thereafter speaks out safely all the high sayings, as many as he will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:41
verses.text: Since any high speech concerning Him, led many into the notion just mentioned, he first sets down what is humiliating and then safely mounts up as high as he pleases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:42
verses.text: And having said, "whom He appointed heir of all things," and that "by Him He made the worlds," he then adds, "and upholding all things by the word of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:43
verses.text: For He that by a word only governs all things, could not be in need of any one, for the producing all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:44
verses.text: And to prove this, mark how again going forward, and laying aside the "by whom," he assigns to Him absolute power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:45
verses.text: For after he had effected what he wished by the use of it, thenceforward leaving it, what saith he? "Thou Lord in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the works of Thine hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:46
verses.text: (Infra, ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:47
verses.text: ) Nowhere is there the saying "by whom," or that "by Him He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:48
verses.text: What then? Were they not made by Him? Yes, but not, as thou sayest or imaginest, "as by an instrument": nor as though He would not have made them unless the Father had reached out a hand to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:49
verses.text: For as He "judgeth no man" ( John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:50
verses.text: ), and is said to judge by the Son, in that He begat Him a judge; so also, to create by Him, in that He begat Him a Creator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:51
verses.text: And if the Father be the original cause of Him, in that He is Father, much more of the things which have been made by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:52
verses.text: When therefore he would show that He is of Him, he speaks of necessity lowly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:53
verses.text: But when he would utter high things, Marcellus takes a handle, and Sabellius; avoiding however the excess of both, he holds a middle [way].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:54
verses.text: For neither does he dwell on the humiliation, lest Paul of Samosata should obtain a standing place, nor yet does he for ever abide in the high sayings; but shows on the contrary His abundant nearness, lest Sabellius rush in upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:55
verses.text: He names Him "Son," and immediately Paul of Samosata comes on him, saying that He is a son, as the many are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:56
verses.text: But he gives him a fatal wound, calling Him "Heir".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:57
verses.text: But yet, with Arius, he is shameless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:58
verses.text: For the saying, "He appointed Him heir," they both hold: the former one saying, it comes of weakness; the other still presses objections, endeavoring to support himself by the clause which follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:59
verses.text: For by saying, "by whom also He made the worlds," he strikes backwards the impudent Samosatene: while Arius still seems to be strong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:60
verses.text: Nevertheless see how he smites him likewise, saying again, "who being the brightness of His glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:61
verses.text: But behold! Sabellius again springs on us, with Marcellus, and Photinus: but on all these also he inflicts one blow, saying, "and the express image of His person and upholding all things by the word of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:62
verses.text: Here again he wounds Marcion too; not very severely, but however he doth wound him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:63
verses.text: For through the whole of this Epistle he is fighting against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:64
verses.text: But the very thing which he said, "the brightness of the glory," hear also Christ Himself saying, "I am the Light of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:65
verses.text: ( John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:66
verses.text: ) Therefore he [the Apostle] uses the word "brightness," showing that this was said in the sense of "Light of Light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:67
verses.text: Nor is it this alone which he shows, but also that He hath enlightened our souls; and He hath Himself manifested the Father, and by "the brightness" he has indicated the nearness of the Being [of the Father and the Son].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:68
verses.text: Observe the subtlety of his expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:69
verses.text: He hath taken one essence and subsistence to indicate two subsistences.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:70
verses.text: Which he also doth in regard to the knowledge of the Spirit ; for as he saith that the knowledge of the Father is one with that of the Spirit, as being indeed one, and in nought varying from itself (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:71
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:72
verses.text: – ): so also here he hath taken hold of one certain [thing] whereby to express the subsistence of the Two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:73
verses.text: And he adds that He is "the express Image".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:74
verses.text: For the "express Image" is something other than its Prototype: yet not Another in all respects, but as to having real subsistence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:75
verses.text: Since here also the term, "express image," indicates there is no variation from that whereof it is the "express image": its similarity in all respects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:76
verses.text: When therefore he calls Him both Form, and express Image, what can they say? "Yea," saith he, "man is also called an Image of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:77
verses.text: What then! is he so [an image of Him] as the Son is? No (saith he) but because the term, image, doth not show resemblance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:78
verses.text: And yet, in that man is called an Image, it showeth resemblance, as in man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:79
verses.text: For what God is in Heaven, that man is on earth, I mean as to dominion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:80
verses.text: And as he hath power over all things on earth, so also hath God power over all things which are in heaven and which are on earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:81
verses.text: But otherwise, man is not called "Express image," he is not called Form: which phrase declares the substance, or rather both substance and similarity in substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:82
verses.text: Therefore just as "the form of a slave" ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:83
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:84
verses.text: ,  ) expresses no other thing than a man without variation [from human nature], so also "the form of God" expresses no other thing than God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:85
verses.text: "Who being" (saith he) "the brightness of His glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:86
verses.text: See what Paul is doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:87
verses.text: Having said, "Who being the brightness of His glory," he added again, "He sat down on the right hand of the Majesty": what names he hath used, nowhere finding a name for the Substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:88
verses.text: For neither "the Majesty," nor "the Glory" setteth forth the Name, which he wishes to say, but is not able to find a name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:89
verses.text: For this is what I said at the beginning, that oftentimes we think something, and are not able to express [it]: since not even the word God is a name of substance, nor is it at all possible to find a name of that Substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:90
verses.text: And what marvel, if it be so in respect of God, since not even in respect of an Angel, could one find a name expressive of his substance? Perhaps too, neither in respect of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:91
verses.text: For this name [soul] doth not seem to me to be significative of the substance thereof, but of breathing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:92
verses.text: For one may see that the same [thing] is called both Soul and Heart and Mind: for, saith he, "Create in me a clean heart, O God" ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:93
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:94
verses.text: ), and one may often see that it [the soul] is called spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:95
verses.text: "And upholding all things by the word of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:96
verses.text: Tell me, "God said" (it is written), "Let there be light" ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:97
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:98
verses.text: ): "the Father, saith one, commanded, and the Son obeyed"? But behold here He also [the Son] acts by word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:99
verses.text: For (saith he), "And upholding all things"—that is, governing; He holds together what would fall to pieces; For, to hold the world together, is no less than to make it, but even greater (if one must say a strange thing).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:100
verses.text: For the one is to bring forward something out of things which are not: but the other, when things which have been made are about to fill back into non-existence, to hold and fasten them together, utterly at variance as they are with each other: this is indeed great and wonderful, and a certain proof of exceeding power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:101
verses.text: Then showing the easiness, he said, "upholding": (he did not say, governing, from the figure of those who simply with their finger move anything, and cause it to go round.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:102
verses.text: ) Here he shows both the mass of the creation to be great, and that this greatness is nothing to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:103
verses.text: Then again he shows the freedom from the labor, saying, "By the word of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:104
verses.text: Well said he, "By the word".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:105
verses.text: For since, with us, a word is accounted to be a bare thing, he shows that it is not bare with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:106
verses.text: But, how "He upholdeth by the word," he hath not further added: for neither is it possible to know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:107
verses.text: Then he added concerning His majesty: for thus John also did: having said that "He is God" ( John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:108
verses.text: ), he brought in the handiwork of the Creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:109
verses.text: For the same thing which the one indirectly expressed, saying, "In the beginning was the Word," and "All things were made by Him" ( John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:110
verses.text: ), this did the other also openly declare by "the Word," and by saying "by whom also He made the worlds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:111
verses.text: For thus he shows Him to be both a Creator, and before all ages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:112
verses.text: What then? when the prophet saith, concerning the Father, "Thou art from everlasting and to everlasting" ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:113
verses.text: xc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:114
verses.text: ), and concerning the Son, that He is before all ages, and the maker of all things—what can they say? Nay rather, when the very thing which was spoken of the Father,—"He which was before the worlds,"—this one may see spoken of the Son also? And that which one saith, "He was life" ( John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:115
verses.text: ), pointing out the preservation of the creation, that Himself is the Life of all things,—so also saith this other, "and upholding all things by the word of His power": not as the Greeks who defraud Him, as much as in them lies, both of Creation itself, and of Providence, shutting up His power, to reach only as far as to the Moon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:116
verses.text: "By Himself" (saith he) "having purged our sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:117
verses.text: Having spoken concerning those marvelous and great matters, which are most above us, he proceeds to speak also afterwards concerning His care for men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:118
verses.text: For indeed the former expression, "and upholding all things," also was universal: nevertheless this is far greater, for it also is universal: for, for His part, "all" men believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:119
verses.text: As John also, having said, "He was life," and so pointed out His providence, saith again, and "He was light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:120
verses.text: "By Himself," saith he, "having purged our sins, He sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:121
verses.text: He here setteth down two very great proofs of His care: first the "purifying us from our sins," then the doing it "by Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:122
verses.text: And in many places, thou seest him making very much of this,—not only of our reconciliation with God, but also of this being accomplished through the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:123
verses.text: For the gift being truly great, was made even greater by the fact that it was through the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:124
verses.text: For in saying, "He sat on the right hand," and, "having by Himself purged our sins,"—though he had put us in mind of the Cross, he quickly added the mention of the resurrection and ascension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:125
verses.text: And see his unspeakable wisdom: he said not, "He was commanded to sit down," but "He sat down".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:126
verses.text: Then again, lest thou shouldest think that He standeth, he subjoins, "For to which of the angels said He at any time, Sit thou on My right hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:127
verses.text: "He sat" (saith he) "on the right hand of the Majesty on high".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:128
verses.text: What is this "on high"? Doth he enclose God in place? Away with such a thought! but just as, when he saith, "on the right hand," he did not describe Him as having figure, but showed His equal dignity with the Father; so, in saying "on high," he did not enclose Him there, but expressed the being higher than all things, and having ascended up above all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:129
verses.text: That is, He attained even unto the very throne of the Father: as therefore the Father is on high, so also is He.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:130
verses.text: For the "sitting together" implies nothing else than equal dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:131
verses.text: But if they say, that He said, "Sit Thou," we may ask them, What then? did He speak to Him standing? Moreover, he said not that He commanded, not that He enjoined, but that "He said": for no other reason, than that thou mightest not think Him without origin and without cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:132
verses.text: For that this is why he said it, is evident from the place of His sitting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:133
verses.text: For had he intended to signify inferiority, he would not have said, "on the right hand," but on the left hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:134
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:135
verses.text: "Being made," saith he, "so much better than the angels, as He hath by inheritance obtained a more excellent name than they".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:136
verses.text: The "being made," here, is instead of "being shown forth," as one may say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:137
verses.text: Then also from what does he reason confidently? From the Name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:138
verses.text: Seest thou that the name Son is wont to declare true relationship? And indeed if He were not a true Son (and "true" is nothing else than "of Him"), how does he reason confidently from this? For if He be Son only by grace, He not only is not "more excellent than the angels," but is even less than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:139
verses.text: How? Because righteous men too were called sons; and the name son, if it be not a genuine son, doth not avail to show the "excellency".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:140
verses.text: When too he would point out that there is a certain difference between creatures and their maker, hear what he saith:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:141
verses.text: "For to which of the Angels said He at any time, Thou art My Son, this day have I begotten Thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:142
verses.text: And again, I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son"? For these things indeed are spoken with reference also to the flesh: "I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son"—while this, "Thou art My Son, this day have I begotten Thee," expresses nothing else than "from [the time] that God is".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:143
verses.text: For as He is said to be, from the time present (for this befits Him more than any other), so also the [word] "To-day" seems to me to be spoken here with reference to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:144
verses.text: For when He hath taken hold of it, thenceforth he speaks out all boldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:145
verses.text: For indeed the flesh partakes of the high things, just as the Godhead of the lowly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:146
verses.text: For He who disdained not to become man, and did not decline the reality, how should He have declined the expressions?  Seeing then that we know these things, let us be ashamed of nothing, nor have any high thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:147
verses.text: For if He Himself being God and Lord and Son of God, did not decline to take the form of a slave, much more ought we to do all things, though they be lowly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:148
verses.text: For tell me, O man, whence hast thou high thoughts? from things of this life? but these or ever they appear, run by.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:149
verses.text: Or, from things spiritual? nay, this is itself one spiritual excellency,—to have no high thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:150
verses.text: Wherefore then dost thou cherish high thoughts? because thou goest on aright? hear Christ saying, "When ye have done all things, say, we are unprofitable servants, for we have done that which was our duty to do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:151
verses.text: ( Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:152
verses.text: )  Or because of thy wealth hast thou high thoughts? Dost thou not see those before thee, how they departed naked and desolate? did we not come naked into life, and naked also shall depart? who hath high thoughts on having what is another's? for they who will use it to their own enjoyment alone, are deprived of it how ever unwillingly, often before death, and at death certainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:153
verses.text: But (saith one) while we live we use them as we will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:154
verses.text: First of all, one doth not lightly see any man using what he hath as he will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:155
verses.text: Next, if a man do even use things as he will, neither is this a great matter: for the present time is short compared with the ages without end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:156
verses.text: Art thou high-minded, O man, because thou art rich? on what account? for what cause? for this befalleth also robbers, and thieves, and man-slayers, and effeminate, and whoremongers, and all sorts of wicked men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:157
verses.text: Wherefore then art thou high-minded? Since if thou hast made meet use of it, thou must not be high-minded, lest thou profane the commandment: but if unmeet, by this indeed [it has come to pass that] thou art become a slave of money, and goods, and art overcome by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:158
verses.text: For tell me, if any man sick of a fever should drink much water, which for a short space indeed quencheth his thirst, but afterwards kindleth the flame, ought he to be high-minded? And what, if any man have many cares without cause, ought he therefore to be high-minded? tell me, wherefore? because thou hast many masters? because thou hast ten thousand cares? because many will flatter thee? [Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:159
verses.text: ] For thou art even their slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:160
verses.text: And to prove that to thee, hear plainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:161
verses.text: The other affections which are within us, are in some cases useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:162
verses.text: For instance, Anger is often useful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:163
verses.text: For (saith he) "unjust wrath shall not be innocent" ( Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:164
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:165
verses.text: ): wherefore it is possible for one to be justly in wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:166
verses.text: And again, "He that is angry with his brother without cause, shall be in danger of hell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:167
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:168
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:169
verses.text: ) Again for instance, emulation, desire, [are useful]: the one when it hath reference to the procreation of children, the other when he directs his emulation to excellent things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:170
verses.text: As Paul also saith, "It is good to be zealously affected always in a good thing" ( Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:171
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:172
verses.text: ) and, "Covet earnestly the best gifts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:173
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:174
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:175
verses.text: ) Both therefore are useful: but an insolent spirit is in no case good, but is always unprofitable and hurtful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:176
verses.text: However, if a man must be proud, [let it be] for poverty, not for wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:177
verses.text: Wherefore? Because he who can live upon a little, is far greater and better than he who cannot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:178
verses.text: For tell me, supposing certain persons called to the Imperial City, if some of them should need neither beasts, nor slaves, nor umbrellas, nor lodging-places, nor sandals, nor vessels, but it should suffice them to have bread, and to take water from the wells,—while others of them should say, "unless ye give us conveyances, and a soft bed, we cannot come; unless also we have many followers, unless we may be allowed continually to rest ourselves, we cannot come, nor unless we have the use of beasts, unless too we may travel but a small portion of the day—and we have need of many other things also": whom should we admire? those or these? plainly, these who require nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:179
verses.text: So also here: some need many things for the journey through this life; others, nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:180
verses.text: So that it would be more fitting to be proud, for poverty if it were fitting at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:181
verses.text: "But the poor man," they say, "is contemptible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:182
verses.text: Not he, but those who despise him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:183
verses.text: For why do not I despise those who know not how to admire what they ought? Why, if a person be a painter, he will laugh to scorn all who jeer at him, so long as they are uninstructed; nor doth he regard the things which they say, but is content with his own testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:184
verses.text: And shall we depend on the opinion of the many? Therefore, we are worthy of contempt when men despise us for our poverty, and we do not despise them nor call them miserable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:185
verses.text: And I say not how many sins are produced by wealth, and how many good things by poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:186
verses.text: But rather, neither wealth nor poverty is excellent in itself, but through those who use it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:187
verses.text: The Christian shines out in poverty rather than in riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:188
verses.text: How? He will be less arrogant, more sober-minded, graver, more equitable, more considerate: but he that is in wealth, hath many impediments to these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:189
verses.text: Let us see then what the rich man does, or rather, he who useth his wealth amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:190
verses.text: Such an one practiceth rapine, fraud, violence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:191
verses.text: Men's unseemly loves, unholy unions, witchcrafts, poisonings, all their other horrors,—wilt thou not find them produced by wealth? Seest thou, that in poverty rather than in wealth the pursuit of virtue is less laborious? For do not, I beseech thee, think that because rich men do not suffer punishment here, neither do they sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:192
verses.text: Since if it were easy for a rich man to suffer punishment, thou wouldest surely have found the prisons filled with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:193
verses.text: But among its other evils, wealth hath this also, that he who possesseth it, transgressing in evil with impunity, will never be stayed from doing so, but will receive wounds without remedies, and no man will put a bridle on him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:194
verses.text: And if a man choose, he will find that poverty affords us more resources even for pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:195
verses.text: How? Because it is freed from cares, hatred, fighting, contention, strife, from evils out of number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:196
verses.text: Therefore let us not follow after wealth, nor be forever envying those who possess much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:197
verses.text: But let those of us who have wealth, use it aright; and those who have not, let us not grieve for this, but give thanks for all things unto God, because He enableth us to receive with little labor the same reward with the rich, or even (if we will) a greater: and from small means we shall have great gains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:198
verses.text: For so he that brought the two talents, was admired and honored equally with him who brought the five.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:199
verses.text: Now why? Because he was entrusted with [but] two talents, yet he accomplished all that in him lay, and brought in what was entrusted to him, doubled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:200
verses.text: Why then are we eager to have much entrusted to us, when we may by a little reap the same fruits, or even greater? when the labor indeed is less, but the reward much more? For more easily will a poor man part with his own, than a rich man who hath many and great possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:201
verses.text: What, know ye not, that the more things a man hath, the more he setteth his love upon? Therefore, lest this befall us, let us not seek after wealth, nor let us be impatient of poverty, nor make haste to be rich: and let those of us who have [riches] so use them as Paul commanded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:202
verses.text: ("They that have," saith he, "as though they had not, and they that use this world as not abusing it"—  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:203
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:204
verses.text: ,  ): that we may obtain the good things promised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 3:205
verses.text: And may it be granted to us all to obtain them, by the grace and love of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now, and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:2
verses.text: Hebrews i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:3
verses.text: –  "And again when He bringeth in the First-Begotten into the world, He saith, And let all the angels of God worship Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:4
verses.text: And of the Angels He saith, Who maketh His angels spirits, and His ministers a flame of fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:5
verses.text: But unto the Son He saith, Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:6
verses.text: Our Lord Jesus Christ calls His coming in the flesh an exodus [or going out]: as when He saith, "The sower went out to sow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:7
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:8
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 4:9
