verses.text: )  They called themselves therefore "strangers"; but Paul said somewhat much beyond this: for not merely did he call himself a stranger, but said that he was dead to the world, and that the world was dead to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:12
verses.text: "For the world" (he says) "has been crucified to me and I to the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:13
verses.text: ( Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:14
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:15
verses.text: ) But we, both citizens and quite alive, busy ourselves about everything here as citizens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:16
verses.text: And what righteous men were to the world, "strangers" and "dead," that we are to Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:17
verses.text: And what they were to Heaven, alive and acting as citizens, that we are to the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:18
verses.text: Wherefore we are dead, because we have refused that which is truly life, and have chosen this which is but for a time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:19
verses.text: Wherefore we have provoked God to wrath, because when the enjoyments of Heaven have been set before us, we are not willing to be separated from things on earth, but, like worms, we turn about from the earth to the earth, and again from this to that; and in short are not willing to look up even for a little while, nor to withdraw ourselves from human affairs, but as if drowned in torpor and sleep and drunkenness, we are stupefied with imaginations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:20
verses.text: And as those who are under the power of sweet sleep lie on their bed not only during the night, but even when the morning has over-taken them, and bright day has come, and are not ashamed to indulge in pleasure, and to make the season of business and activity a time of slumber and indolence, so truly we also, when the day is drawing near, when the night is far spent, or rather the day; for "work" (it is said) "while it is day" ( John ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:21
verses.text: ); when it is day we practice all that belongs to the night, sleeping, dreaming, indulging in luxurious fancies; and the eyes of our understanding are closed as well as those of our body; we speak amiss, we talk absurdly; even if a person inflict a deep wound upon us, if he carry off all our substance, if he set the very house on fire, we are not so much as conscious of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:22
verses.text: Or rather, we do not even wait for others to do this, but we do it ourselves, piercing and wounding ourselves every day, lying in unseemly fashion, and stripped bare of all credit, all honor, neither ourselves concealing our shameful deeds, nor permitting others to do so, but lying exposed to public shame, to the ridicule, the numberless jests of spectators and passers-by.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:23
verses.text: Do ye not suppose that the wicked themselves laugh at those who are of like characters to themselves, and condemn them? For since God has placed within us a tribunal which cannot be bribed nor ever utterly destroyed, even though we come to the very lowest depth of vice; therefore even the wicked themselves give sentence against themselves, and if one call them that which they are, they are ashamed, they are angry, they say that it is an insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:24
verses.text: Thus they condemn what they do, even if not by their deeds, yet by their words, by their conscience, nay rather even by their deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:25
verses.text: For when they carry on their practices out of sight and secretly, they give the strongest proof of the opinion they hold concerning the thing itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:26
verses.text: For wickedness is so manifest, that all men are its accusers, even those who follow after it, while such is the quality of virtue, that it is admired even by those who do not emulate it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:27
verses.text: For even the fornicator will praise chastity, and the covetous will condemn injustice, and the passionate will admire patience, and blame quarrelsomeness, and the wanton [will blame] wantonness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:28
verses.text: How then (you say) does he pursue these things? From excessive indolence, not because he judges it good; otherwise he would not have been ashamed of the thing itself, nor would he have denied it when another accused him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:29
verses.text: Nay many when caught, not enduring the shame, have even hanged themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:30
verses.text: So strong is the witness within us in behalf of what is good and becoming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:31
verses.text: Thus what is good is brighter than the sun, and the contrary more unsightly than anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:32
verses.text: The saints were "strangers and sojourners".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:33
verses.text: How and in what way? And where does Abraham confess himself "a stranger and a sojourner"? Probably indeed he even himself confessed it: but David both confessed "I am a stranger" and what? "As all my fathers were".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:34
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:35
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:36
verses.text: ) For they who dwell in tents, they who purchase even burial places for money, evidently were in some sense strangers, as they had not even where to bury their dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:37
verses.text: What then? Did they mean that they were "strangers" from the land that is in Palestine? By no means: but in respect of the whole world: and with reason; for they saw therein none of the things which they wished for, but everything foreign and strange.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:38
verses.text: They indeed wished to practice virtue: but here there was much wickedness, and things were quite foreign to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:39
verses.text: They had no friend, no familiar acquaintance, save only some few.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:40
verses.text: But how were they "strangers"? They had no care for things here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:41
verses.text: And this they showed not by words, but by their deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:42
verses.text: In what way?  He said to Abraham, "Leave that which seems thy country and come to one that is foreign": And he did not cleave to his kindred, but gave it up as unconcernedly as if he were about to leave a foreign land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:43
verses.text: He said to him, "Offer up thy son," and he offered him up as if he had no son; as if he had divested himself of his nature, so he offered him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:44
verses.text: The wealth which he had acquired was common to all passers-by, and this he accounted as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:45
verses.text: He yielded the first places to others: he threw himself into dangers; he suffered troubles innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:46
verses.text: He built no splendid houses, he enjoyed no luxuries, he had no care about dress, which all are things of this world; but lived in all respects as belonging to the City yonder; he showed hospitality, brotherly love, mercifulness, forbearance, contempt for wealth and for present glory, and for all else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:47
verses.text: And his son too was such as himself: when he was driven away, when war was made on him, he yielded and gave way, as being in a foreign land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:48
verses.text: For foreigners, whatever they suffer, endure it, as not being in their own country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:49
verses.text: Even when his wife was taken from him, he endured this also as being in a strange land: and lived in all respects as one whose home was above, showing sobermindedness and a well-ordered life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:50
verses.text: For after he had begotten a son, he had no more commerce with his wife, and it was when the flower of his youth had passed that he married her, showing that he did it not from passion, but in subservience to the promise of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:51
verses.text: And what did Jacob? Did he not seek bread only and raiment, which are asked for by those who are truly strangers; by those that have come to great poverty? When he was driven out, did he not as a stranger give place? Did he not serve for hire? Did he not suffer afflictions innumerable, everywhere, as a stranger?   And these things (he says) they said, "seeking" their "own country".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:52
verses.text: Ah! how great is the difference! They indeed were in travail-pains each day, wishing to be released from this world, and to return to their country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:53
verses.text: But we, on the contrary, if a fever attack us, neglecting everything, weeping like little children, are frightened at death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:54
verses.text: Not without reason we are thus affected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:55
verses.text: For since we do not live here like strangers, nor as if hastening to our country, but are like persons that are going away to punishment, therefore we grieve, because we have not used circumstances as we ought, but have turned order upside down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:56
verses.text: Hence we grieve when we ought to rejoice: hence we shudder, like murderers or robber chiefs, when they are going to be brought before the judgment-seat, and are thinking over all the things they have done, and therefore are fearful and trembling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:57
verses.text: They, however, were not such, but pressed on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:58
verses.text: And Paul even groaned; "And we" (he says) "that are in this tabernacle do groan, being burdened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:59
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:60
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:61
verses.text: ) Such were they who were with Abraham; "strangers," he says, they were in respect of the whole world, and "they sought a country".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:62
verses.text: What sort of "country" was this? Was it that which they had left? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:63
verses.text: For what hindered them if they wished, from returning again, and becoming citizens? but they sought that which is in Heaven? Thus they desired their departure hence, and so they pleased God; for "God was not ashamed to be called their God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:64
verses.text: Ah! how great a dignity! He vouch-safed "to be called their God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:65
verses.text: What dost thou say? He is called the God of the earth, and the God of Heaven, and hast thou set it down as a great thing that "He is not ashamed to be called their God"? Great and truly great this is, and a proof of exceeding blessedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:66
verses.text: How? Because He is called God of earth and of heaven as also of the Gentiles: in that He created and formed them: but [God] of those holy men, not in this sense, but as some true friend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:67
verses.text: And I will make it plain to you by an example; as in the case of [slaves] in large households, when any of those placed over the household are very highly esteemed, and manage everything themselves, and can use great freedom towards their masters, the Master is called after them, and one may find many so called.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:68
verses.text: But what do I say? As we might say the God, not of the Gentiles but of the world, so we might say "the God of Abraham".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:69
verses.text: But you do not know how great a dignity this is, because we do not attain to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:70
verses.text: For as now He is called the Lord of all Christians, and yet the name goes beyond our deserts: consider the greatness if He were called the God of one [person]! He who is called the God of the whole world is "not ashamed to be called" the God of three men: and with good reason: for the saints would turn the scale, I do not say against the world but against ten thousand such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:71
verses.text: "For one man who doeth the will of the Lord, is better than ten thousand transgressors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:72
verses.text: ( Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:73
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:74
verses.text: )  Now that they called themselves "strangers" in this sense is manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:75
verses.text: But supposing that they said they were "strangers" on account of the strange land, why did David also [call himself a stranger]? Was not he a king? Was not he a prophet? Did he not spend his life in his own country? Why then does he say, "I am a stranger and a sojourner"? ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:76
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:77
verses.text: ) How art thou a stranger? "As" (he says) "all my fathers were".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:78
verses.text: Seest thou that they too were strangers? We have a country, he means, but not really our country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:79
verses.text: But how art thou thyself a stranger? As to the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:80
verses.text: Therefore they also [were strangers] in respect of the earth: For "as they were," he says, so also am I; and as he, so they too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:81
verses.text: Let us even now become strangers; that God may "not be ashamed of us to be called our God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:82
verses.text: For it is a shame to Him, when He is called the God of the wicked, and He also is ashamed of them; as He is glorified when He is [called the God] of the good and the kind, and of them that cultivate virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:83
verses.text: For if "we" decline to be called the masters of our wicked slaves, and give them up; and should any one come to us and say, 'such a one does innumerable bad things, he is your slave, is he not?' We immediately say, "by no means," to get rid of the disgrace: for a slave has a close relation to his master, and the discredit passes from the one to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:84
verses.text: —But they were so illustrious, so full of confidence, that not only was He "not ashamed to be called" from them, but He even Himself says, "I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:85
verses.text: ( Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:86
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:87
verses.text: )  Let us also, my beloved, become "strangers"; that God may "not be ashamed of us"; that He may not be ashamed, and deliver us up to Hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:88
verses.text: Such were they who said, "Lord, have we not prophesied in Thy Name, and in Thy Name have done many wonderful works!" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:89
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:90
verses.text: ) But see what Christ says to them: "I know you not:" the very thing which masters would do, when wicked slaves run to them, wishing to be rid of the disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:91
verses.text: "I know you not," He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:92
verses.text: How then dost Thou punish those whom Thou knowest not? I said, "I know not," in a different sense: that is, "I deny you, and renounce you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:93
verses.text: But God forbid that we should hear this fatal and terrible utterance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:94
verses.text: For if they who cast out demons and prophesied, were denied, because their life was not suitable thereto; how much more we!   And how (you ask) is it possible that they should be denied, who have shown prophetic powers, and wrought miracles, and cast out demons? Is it probable they were afterwards changed, and became wicked; and therefore were nothing benefited, even by their former virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:95
verses.text: For not only ought we to have our beginnings splendid, but the end also more splendid still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:96
verses.text: For tell me, does not the Orator take pains to make the end of his speech splendid, that he may retire with applause? Does not the public officer make the most splendid display at the close of his administration? The wrestler, if he do not make a more splendid display and conquer unto the end, and if after vanquishing all he be vanquished by the last, is not all unprofitable to him? Should the pilot have crossed the whole ocean, yet if he wreck his vessel at the port, has he not lost all his former labor? And what [of] the Physician? If, after he has freed the sick man from his disease, when he is on the point of discharging him cured, he should then destroy him, has he not destroyed everything? So too in respect of Virtue, as many as have not added an end suitable to the beginning, and in unison and harmony with it, are ruined, and undone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:97
verses.text: Such are they who have sprung forth from the starting place bright and exulting, and afterwards have become faint and feeble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:98
verses.text: Therefore they are both deprived of the prize, and are not acknowledged by their master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:99
verses.text: Let us listen to these things, those of us who are in love of wealth: for this is the greatest iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:100
verses.text: "For the love of money is the root of all evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:101
verses.text: (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:102
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:103
verses.text: ) Let us listen, those of us who wish to make our present possessions greater, let us listen and sometime cease from our covetousness, that we may not hear the same things as they [will hear].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:104
verses.text: Let us listen to them now, and be on our guard, that we may not hear them then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:105
verses.text: Let us listen now with fear, that we may not then listen with vengeance: "Depart from Me" (He says); "I never knew you" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:106
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:107
verses.text: ), no not even then (He means) when ye made a display of prophesyings, and were casting out demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:108
verses.text: It is probable that He also here hints at something else, that even then they were wicked; and from the beginning, grace wrought even by the unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:109
verses.text: For if it wrought through Balaam, much more through the unworthy, for the sake of those who shall profit [by it].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:110
verses.text: But if even signs and wonders did not avail to deliver from punishment; much more, if a man happen to be in the priestly dignity: even if he reach the highest honor, even if grace work in him to ordination, even if unto all the other things, for the sake of those who need his leadership, he also shall hear, "I never knew thee," no, not even then when grace wrought in thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:111
verses.text: O! how strict shall the search be there as to purity of life! How does that, of itself, suffice to introduce us into the kingdom? While the absence of it gives up the man [to destruction], though he have ten thousand miracles and signs to show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:112
verses.text: For nothing is so pleasing to God as an excellent course of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:113
verses.text: "If ye love Me" ( John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:114
verses.text: ), He declares; He did not say, "work miracles," but what? "Keep My commandments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:115
verses.text: And again, "I call you friends" ( John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:116
verses.text: ), not when ye cast out demons, but "if ye keep My words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:117
verses.text: For those things come of the gift of God: but these after the gift of God, of our own diligence also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:118
verses.text: Let us strive to become friends of God, and not remain enemies to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:119
verses.text: These things we are ever saying, these exhortations we are ever giving, both to ourselves and to you: but nothing more is gained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:120
verses.text: Wherefore also I am afraid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:121
verses.text: And I would have wished indeed to be silent, so as not to increase your danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:122
verses.text: For when a person often hears, and even so does not act, this is to provoke the Lord to anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:123
verses.text: But I fear also myself that other danger, that of silence, if when I am ap pointed to the ministering of the word, I should hold my peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:124
verses.text: What shall we then do that we may be saved? Let us begin [the practice of] virtue, as we have opportunity: let us portion out the virtues to ourselves, as laborers do their husbandry; in this month let us master evil-speaking, injuriousness, unjust anger; and let us lay down a law for ourselves, and say, To-day let us set this right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:125
verses.text: Again, in this month let us school ourselves in forbearance, and in another, in some other virtue: And when we have got into the habit of this virtue let us go to another, just as in the things we learn at school, guarding what is already gained, and acquiring others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:126
verses.text: After this let us proceed to contempt for riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:127
verses.text: First let us restrain our hands from grasping, and then let us give alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:128
verses.text: Let us not simply confound everything, with the same hands both slaying and showing mercy forsooth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:129
verses.text: After this, let us go to some other virtue, and from that, to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:130
verses.text: "Filthiness and foolish talking and jesting, let it not be even named among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:131
verses.text: ( Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:132
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:134
verses.text: ) Let us be thus far in the right way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:135
verses.text: There is no need of spending money, there is no need of labor, none of sweat, it is enough to have only the will, and all is done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:136
verses.text: There is no need to travel a long way, nor to cross a boundless ocean, but to be in earnest and of ready mind, and to put a bridle on the tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:137
verses.text: Unseasonable reproaches, anger, disorderly lusts, luxuriousness, expensiveness, let us cast off; and the desire of wealth also from our soul, perjury and habitual oaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:138
verses.text: If we thus cultivate ourselves, plucking out the former thorns, and casting in the heavenly seed, we shall be able to attain the good things promised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 25:139
verses.text: For the Husbandman will come and will lay us up in His Garner, and we shall attain to all good things, which may we all attain, by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:1
verses.text: Homily XXV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:2
verses.text: Hebrews xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:3
verses.text: –  "By faith [Abraham], when he was tried, offered up Isaac; and he that had received the promises offered up his only-begotten son, of whom it was said, That in Isaac shall thy seed be called: accounting that God was able to raise him up even from the dead; from whence also he received him in a figure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:4
verses.text: Great indeed was the faith of Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:5
verses.text: For while in the case of Abel, and of Noah, and of Enoch, there was an opposition of reasonings only, and it was necessary to go beyond human reasonings; in this case it was necessary not only to go beyond human reasonings, but to manifest also something more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:6
verses.text: For what was of God seemed to be opposed to what was of God; and faith opposed faith, and command promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:7
verses.text: I mean this: He had said, "Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and I will give thee this land".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:8
verses.text: ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:9
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:11
verses.text: ) "He gave him none inheritance in it, no not so much as to set his foot on".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:12
verses.text: ( Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:13
verses.text: ) Seest thou how what was done was opposed to the promise? Again He said, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called" ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:14
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:15
verses.text: ), and he believed: and again He says, Sacrifice to Me this one, who was to fill all the world from his seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:16
verses.text: Thou seest the opposition between the commands and the promise? He enjoined things that were in contradiction to the promises, and yet not even so did the righteous man stagger, nor say he had been deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:17
verses.text: For you indeed, he means, could not say this, that He promised ease and gave tribulation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:18
verses.text: For in our case, the things which He promised, these also He performs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:19
verses.text: How so? "In the world" (He says), "ye shall have tribulation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:20
verses.text: ( John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:21
verses.text: ) "He that taketh not his cross and followeth Me, is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:22
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:23
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:24
verses.text: ) "He that hateth not his life shall not find it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:25
verses.text: ( John xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:26
verses.text: ) And, "He that forsaketh not all that he hath, and followeth after Me, is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:27
verses.text: ( Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:29
verses.text: ) And again, "Ye shall be brought before rulers and kings for My sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:30
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:31
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:32
verses.text: ) And again, "A man's foes shall be they of his own household".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:33
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:34
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:35
verses.text: ) But the things which pertain to rest are yonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:36
verses.text: But with regard to Abraham, it was different.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:37
verses.text: He was enjoined to do what was opposed to the promises; and yet not even so was he troubled, nor did he stagger, nor think he had been deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:38
verses.text: But you endure nothing except what was promised, yet you are troubled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:39
verses.text: He heard the opposite of the promises from Him who had made them; and yet he was not disturbed, but did them as if they had been in harmony [therewith].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:40
verses.text: For they were in harmony; being opposed indeed according to human calculations, but in harmony [when viewed] by Faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:41
verses.text: And how this was, the Apostle himself has taught us, by saying, "accounting that God was able to raise Him up, even from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:42
verses.text: By the same faith (he means) by which he believed that God gave what was not, and raised up the dead, by the same was he persuaded that He would also raise him up after he had been slain in sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:43
verses.text: For it was alike impossible (to human calculation, I mean) from a womb which was dead and grown old and already become useless for child-bearing to give a child, and to raise again one who had been slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:44
verses.text: But his previous faith prepared the way for things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:45
verses.text: And see; the good things came first, and the hard things afterwards, in his old age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:46
verses.text: But for you, on the contrary, (he says) the sad things are first, and the good things last.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:47
verses.text: This for those who dare to say, 'He has promised us the good things after death; perhaps He has deceived us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:48
verses.text: ' He shows that "God is able to raise up even from the dead," and if God be able to raise from the dead, without all doubt He will pay all [that He has promised].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:49
verses.text: But if Abraham so many years before, believed "that God is able to raise from the dead," much more ought we to believe it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:50
verses.text: Thou seest (what I at first said) that death had not yet entered in and yet He drew them at once to the hope of the resurrection, and led them to such full assurance, that when bidden, they even slay their own sons, and readily offer up those from whom they expected to people the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:51
verses.text: And he shows another thing too, by saying, that "God tempted Abraham".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:52
verses.text: ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:53
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:54
verses.text: ) What then? Did not God know that the man was noble and approved? Why then did He tempt him? Not that He might Himself learn, but that He might show to others, and make his fortitude manifest to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:55
verses.text: And here also he shows the cause of trials, that they may not suppose they suffer these things as being forsaken [of God].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:56
verses.text: For in their case indeed, it was necessary that they should he tried, because there were many who persecuted or plotted against them: but in Abraham's case, what need was there to devise trials for him which did not exist? Now this trial, it is evident, was by His command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:57
verses.text: The others indeed happened by His allowance, but this even by His command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:58
verses.text: If then temptations make men approved in such wise that, even where there is no occasion, God exercises His own athletes; much more ought we to bear all things nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:59
verses.text: And here he said emphatically, "By faith, when he was tried, he offered up Isaac," for there was no other cause for his bringing the offering but that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:60
verses.text: After this he pursues the same thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:61
verses.text: No one (he says) could allege, that he had another son, and expected the promise to be fulfilled from him, and therefore confidently offered up this one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:62
verses.text: "And" (his words are) "he offered up his only-begotten, who had received the promises".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:63
verses.text: Why sayest thou "only-begotten"? What then? Of whom was Ishmael sprung? I mean "only-begotten" (he would say) so far as relates to the word of the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:64
verses.text: Therefore after saying, "Only-begotten," showing that he says it for this reason, he added, "of whom it was said, In Isaac shall thy seed be called," that is, "from" him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:65
verses.text: Seest thou how he admires what was done by the Patriarch? "In Isaac shall thy seed be called," and that son he brought to be sacrificed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:66
verses.text: Afterwards, that no one may suppose he does this in despair, and in consequence of this command had cast away that Faith, but may understand that this also was truly of faith, he says that he retained that faith also, although it seem to be at variance with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:67
verses.text: But it was not at variance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:68
verses.text: For he did not measure the power of God by human reasonings, but committed all to faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:69
verses.text: And hence he was not afraid to say, that God was "able to raise him up, even from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:70
verses.text: "From whence also he received him in a figure," that is in idea, by the ram, he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:71
verses.text: How? The ram having been slain, he was saved: so that by means of the ram he received him again, having slain it in his stead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:72
verses.text: But these things were types: for here it is the Son of God who is slain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:73
verses.text: And observe, I beseech you, how great is His lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:74
verses.text: For inasmuch as a great favor was to be given to men, He, wishing to do this, not by favor, but as a debtor, arranges that a man should first give up his own son on account of God's command, in order that He Himself might seem to be doing nothing great in giving up His own Son, since a man had done this before Him; that He might be supposed to do it not of grace, but of debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:75
verses.text: For we wish to do this kindness also to those whom we love, others, to appear first to have received some little thing from them, and so give them all: and we boast more of the receiving than of the giving; and we do not say, We gave him this, but, We received this from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:76
verses.text: "From whence also" (are his words) "he received him in a figure," i-e: as in a riddle (for the ram was as it were a figure of Isaac) or, as in a type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:77
verses.text: For since the sacrifice had been completed, and Isaac slain in purpose, therefore He gave him to the Patriarch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:78
verses.text: Thou seest, that what I am constantly saying, is shown in this case also? When we have proved that our mind is made perfect, and have shown that we disregard earthly things, then earthly things also are given to us; but not before; lest being bound to them already, receiving them we should be bound still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:79
verses.text: Loose thyself from thy slavery first (He says), and then receive, that thou mayest receive no longer as a slave, but as a master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:80
verses.text: Despise riches, and thou shalt be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:81
verses.text: Despise glory, and thou shalt be glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:82
verses.text: Despise the avenging thyself on thine enemies, and then shalt thou attain it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:83
verses.text: Despise repose, and then thou shalt receive it that in receiving thou mayest receive not as a prisoner, nor as a slave, but as a freeman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:84
verses.text: For as in the case of little children, when the child eagerly desires childish playthings, we hide them from him with much care, as a ball, for instance, and such like things, that he may not be hindered from necessary things; but when he thinks little of them, and no longer longs for them, we give them fearlessly, knowing that henceforth no harm can come to him from them, the desire no longer having strength enough to draw him away from things necessary; so God also, when He sees that we no longer eagerly desire the things of this world, thenceforward permits us to use them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:85
verses.text: For we possess them as freemen and men, not as children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:86
verses.text: For [in proof] that if thou despise the avenging thyself on thine enemies, thou wilt then attain it, hear what he says, "If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink," and he added, "for in so doing, thou shalt heap coals of fire on his head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:87
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:88
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:89
verses.text: ) And again, that if thou despise riches, thou shalt then obtain them, hear Christ saying, "There is no man which hath left father, or mother, or house, or brethren, who shall not receive an hundredfold, and shall inherit everlasting life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:90
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:91
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:92
verses.text: ) And that if thou despise glory, thou shalt then attain it, again hear Christ Himself saying, "He that will be first among you, let him be your minister".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:93
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:94
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:95
verses.text: ) And again, "For whosoever shall humble himself, he shall be exalted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:96
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:97
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:98
verses.text: )  What sayest thou? If I give drink to mine enemy, do I then punish him? If I give up my goods, do I then possess them? If I humble myself, shall I then be exalted? Yea, He says, for such is My power, to give contraries by means of contraries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:99
verses.text: I abound in resources and in contrivances: be not afraid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:100
verses.text: The 'Nature of things' follows My will: not I attend upon Nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:101
verses.text: I do all things: I am not controlled by them: wherefore also I am able to change their form and order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:102
verses.text: And why dost thou wonder if [it is so] in these instances? For thou wilt find the same also in all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:103
verses.text: If thou injure, thou art injured; if thou art injured, then thou art uninjured; if thou punish, then thou hast not punished another, but hast punished thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:104
verses.text: For "he that loveth iniquity," it is said, "hateth his own soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:105
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:106
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:107
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:108
verses.text: ) Seest thou that thou dost not injure, but art injured? Therefore also Paul says, "Why do ye not rather take wrong?" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:109
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:110
verses.text: ) Dost thou see that this is not to be wronged?  When thou insultest, then art thou insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:111
verses.text: And most persons partly know this: as when they say one to another, "Let us go away, do not disgrace yourself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:112
verses.text: Why? Because the difference is great between thee and him: for however much thou insultest him, he accounts it a credit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:113
verses.text: Let us consider this in all cases, and be above insults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:114
verses.text: I will tell you how.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:115
verses.text: Should we have a contest with him who wears the purple, let us consider that in insulting him, we insult ourselves, for we become worthy to be disgraced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:116
verses.text: Tell me, what dost thou mean? When thou art a citizen of Heaven, and hast the Philosophy that is above, dost thou disgrace thyself with him "that mindeth earthly things"? ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:117
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:118
verses.text: ) For though he be in possession of countless riches, though he be in power, he does not as yet know the good that is therein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:119
verses.text: Do not in insulting him, insult thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:120
verses.text: Spare thyself, not him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:121
verses.text: Honor thyself, not him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:122
verses.text: Is there not some Proverb such as this, He that honoreth; honoreth himself? With good reason: for he honors not the other, but himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:123
verses.text: Hear what a certain wise man says, "Do honor to thy soul according to the dignity thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:124
verses.text: ( Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:125
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:126
verses.text: ) "According to the dignity thereof," what is this? if he have defrauded (it means), do not thou defraud; if he has insulted, do not thou insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:127
verses.text: Tell me, I pray thee, if some poor man has taken away clay thrown out of thy yard, wouldst thou for this have summoned a court of justice? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:128
verses.text: Why? Lest thou shouldst disgrace thyself; lest all men should condemn thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:129
verses.text: The same also happens in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:130
verses.text: For the rich man is poor, and the more rich he is, the poorer is he in that which is indeed poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:131
verses.text: Gold is clay, cast out in the yard, not lying in thy house, for thy house is Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:132
verses.text: For this, then, wilt thou summon a Court of Justice, and will not the citizens on high condemn thee? Will they not cast thee out from their country, who art so mean, who art so shabby, as to choose to fight for a little clay? For if the world were thine, and then some one had taken it, oughtest thou to pay any attention to it?  Knowest thou not, that if thou wert to take the world ten times or an hundred times, or ten thousand times, and twice that, it is not to be compared with the least of the good things in Heaven? He then who admires the things here slights those yonder, since he judges these worthy of exertion, though so far inferior to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:133
verses.text: Nay, rather indeed he will not be able to admire those other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:134
verses.text: For how [can he], whilst he is passionately excited towards these earthly things? Let us cut through the cords and entanglements: for this is what earthly things are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:135
verses.text: How long shall we be stooping down? How long shall we plot one against another, like wild beasts; like fishes? Nay rather, the wild beasts do not plot against each other, but [against] animals of a different tribe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:136
verses.text: A bear for instance does not readily kill a bear, nor a serpent kill a serpent, having respect for the sameness of race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:137
verses.text: But thou, with one of the same race, and having innumerable claims, as common origin, rational faculties, the knowledge of God, ten thousand other things, the force of nature, him who is thy kinsman, and partaker of the same nature—him thou killest, and involvest in evils innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:138
verses.text: For what, if thou dost not thrust thy sword, nor plunge thy right hand into his neck, other things more grievous than this thou doest, when thou involvest him in innumerable evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:139
verses.text: For if thou hadst done the other, thou wouldst have freed him from anxiety, but now thou encompassest him with hunger, with slavery, with feelings of discouragement, with many sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:140
verses.text: These things I say, and shall not cease to say, not [as] preparing you to commit murder: nor as urging you to some crime short of that; but that you may not be confident, as if you were not to give account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:141
verses.text: "For" (it says) "he that taketh away a livelihood" ( Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:142
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:143
verses.text: ) and asketh bread, it says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:144
verses.text: Let us at length keep our hands to ourselves, or rather, let us not keep them, but stretch them out honorably, not for grasping, but for alms-giving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:145
verses.text: Let us not have our hand unfruitful nor withered; for the hand which doeth not alms is withered; and that which is also grasping, is polluted and unclean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:146
verses.text: Let no one eat with such hands; for this is an insult to those invited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:147
verses.text: For, tell me, if a man when he had made us lie down on tapestry and a soft couch and linen interwoven with gold, in a great and splendid house, and had set by us a great multitude of attendants, and had prepared a tray of silver and gold, and filled it with many dainties of great cost and of all sorts, then urged us to eat, provided we would only endure his besmearing his hands with mire or with human ordure, and so sitting down to meat with us—would any man endure this infliction? Would he not rather have considered it an insult? Indeed I think he would, and would have gone straightway off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:148
verses.text: But now in fact, thou seest not hands filled with what is indeed filth, but even the very food, and yet thou dost not go off, nor flee, nor find fault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:149
verses.text: Nay, if he be a person in authority, thou even accountest it a grand affair, and destroyest thine own soul, in eating such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:150
verses.text: For covetousness is worse than any mire; for it pollutes, not the body but the soul, and makes it hard to be washed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:151
verses.text: Thou therefore, though thou seest him that sitteth at meat defiled with this filth both on his hands and his face, and his house filled with it, nay and his table also full of it (for dung, or if there be anything more unclean than that, it is not so unclean and polluted as those viands), dost thou feel as if forsooth thou wert highly honored, and as if thou wert going to enjoy thyself?  And dost thou not fear Paul who allows us to go without restraint to the Tables of the heathen if we wish, but not even if we wish to those of the covetous? For, "if any man who is called a Brother" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:152
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:153
verses.text: ), he says, meaning here by Brother every one who is a believer simply, not him who leads a solitary life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:154
verses.text: For what is it which makes brotherhood? The Washing of regeneration; the being enabled to call God our Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:155
verses.text: So that he that is a Monk, if he be a Catechumen, is not a Brother, but the believer though he be in the world, is a Brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:156
verses.text: "If any man," saith he, "that is called a Brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:157
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:158
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:159
verses.text: ) For at that time there was not even a trace of any one leading a Monastic life, but this blessed [Apostle] addressed all his discourse to persons in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:160
verses.text: "If any man," he says, "that is called a Brother, be a fornicator, or covetous or a drunkard, with such an one, no not to eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:161
verses.text: But not so with respect to the heathen: but "If any of them that believe not," meaning the heathen, "bid you and ye be disposed to go, whatsoever is set before you eat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:162
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:163
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:164
verses.text: )   "If any man that is called Brother be" (he says) "a drunkard".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:165
verses.text: Oh! what strictness! Yet we not only do not avoid drunkards, but even go to their houses, partaking of what they set before us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:166
verses.text: Therefore all things are upside down, all things are in confusion, and overthrown, and ruined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:167
verses.text: For tell me, if any such person should invite thee to a banquet, thee who art accounted poor and mean, and then should hear thee say, "Inasmuch as the things set before me are [the fruit] of overreaching, I will not endure to defile my own soul," would he not be mortified? Would he not be confounded? Would he not be ashamed? This alone were sufficient to correct him, and to make him call himself wretched for his wealth, and admire thee for thy poverty, if he saw himself with so great earnestness despised by thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:168
verses.text: But we "are become" (I know not why) "servants of men" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:169
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:170
verses.text: ), though Paul cries aloud throughout, "Be not ye the servants of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:171
verses.text: Whence then have we become "servants of men"? Because we first became servants of the belly, and of money, and of glory, and of all the rest; we gave up the liberty which Christ bestowed on us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:172
verses.text: What then awaiteth him who is become a servant (tell me)? Hear Christ saying, "The servant abideth not in the house for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:173
verses.text: ( John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:174
verses.text: ) Thou hast a declaration complete in itself, that he never entereth into the Kingdom; for this is what "the House" means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:175
verses.text: For, He says, "in My Father's House are many mansions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:176
verses.text: ( John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:177
verses.text: ) "The servant" then "abideth not in the House for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:178
verses.text: By a servant He means him who is "the servant of sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:179
verses.text: But he that "abideth not in the House for ever," abideth in Hell for ever, having no consolation from any quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:180
verses.text: Nay, to this point of wickedness are matters come, that they even give alms out of these [ill-gotten gains], and many receive [them].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:181
verses.text: Therefore our boldness has broken down, and we are not able to rebuke any one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 26:182
verses.text: But however, henceforward at least, let us flee the mischief arising from this; and ye who have rolled yourselves in this mire, cease from such defilement, and restrain your rage for such banquets, if even now we may by any means be able to have God propitious to us, and to attain to the good things which have been promised: which may we all obtain in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:1
verses.text: Homily XXVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:2
verses.text: Hebrews xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:3
verses.text: –  "By faith, Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:4
verses.text: By faith, Jacob when he was a dying blessed both the sons of Joseph, and worshiped leaning on the top of his staff.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:5
verses.text: By faith, Joseph when he died made mention of the departing of the children of Israel, and gave commandment concerning his bones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:6
verses.text: "Many prophets and righteous men" (it is said) "have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them; and to hear those things which ye hear and have not heard them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:7
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:8
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:9
verses.text: ) Did then those righteous men know all the things to come? Yea, most certainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:10
verses.text: For if because of the weakness of those who were not able to receive Him, the Son was not revealed,—He was with good reason revealed to those conspicuous in virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:11
verses.text: This Paul also says, that they knew "the things to come," that is the resurrection of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:12
verses.text: Or he does not mean this: but that "By faith, concerning things to come" [means] not [concerning] the world to come, but "concerning things to come" in this world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:13
verses.text: For how [except by faith] could a man sojourning in a strange land, give such blessings?  But on the other hand he obtained the blessing, and yet did not receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:14
verses.text: Thou seest that what I said with regard to Abraham, may be said also of Jacob, that they did not enjoy the blessing, but the blessings went to his posterity, while he himself obtained the "things to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:15
verses.text: For we find that his brother rather enjoyed the blessing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:16
verses.text: For [Jacob] spent all his time in servitude and working as a hireling, and [amid] dangers, and plots, and deceits, and fears; and when he was asked by Pharaoh, he says, "Few and evil have my days been" ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:17
verses.text: xlvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:18
verses.text: ); while the other lived in independence and great security, and afterwards was an object of terror to [Jacob].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:19
verses.text: Where then did the blessings come to their accomplishment, save in the [world] to come?  Seest thou that from the beginning the wicked have enjoyed things here, but the righteous the contrary? Not however all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:20
verses.text: For behold, Abraham was a righteous man, and he enjoyed things here as well, though with affliction and trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:21
verses.text: For indeed wealth was all he had, seeing all else relating to him was full of affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:22
verses.text: For it is impossible that the righteous man should not be afflicted, though he be rich: for when he is willing to be overreached, to be wronged, to suffer all other things, he must be afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:23
verses.text: So that although he enjoy wealth, [yet is it] not without grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:24
verses.text: Why? you ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:25
verses.text: Because he is in affliction and distress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:26
verses.text: But if at that time the righteous were in affliction, much more now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:27
verses.text: "By Faith," he says, "Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come" (and yet Esau was the elder; but he puts Jacob first for his excellence).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:28
verses.text: Seest thou how great was his Faith? Whence did he promise to his sons so great blessings? Entirely from his having faith in God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:29
verses.text: "By Faith, Jacob when he was a dying, blessed both the sons of Joseph".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:30
verses.text: Here we ought to set down the blessings entire, in order that both his faith and his prophesying may be made manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:31
verses.text: "And worshiped leaning," he says, "upon the top of his staff".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:32
verses.text: Here, he means, he not only spoke, but was even so confident about the future things, as to show it also by his act.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:33
verses.text: For inasmuch as another King was about to arise from Ephraim, therefore it is said, "And he bowed himself upon the top of his staff".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:34
verses.text: That is, even though he was now an old man, "he bowed himself" to Joseph, showing the obeisance of the whole people which was to be [directed] to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:35
verses.text: And this indeed had already taken place, when his brethren "bowed down" to him: but it was afterwards to come to pass through the ten tribes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:36
verses.text: Seest thou how he foretold the things which were to be afterwards? Seest thou how great faith they had? How they believed "concerning the things to come"?  For some of the things here, the things present, are examples of patience only, and of enduring ill-treatment, and of receiving nothing good; for instance, what is mentioned in the case of Abraham, in the case of Abel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:37
verses.text: But others are [examples] of Faith, as in the case of Noah, that there is a God, that there is a recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:38
verses.text: (For Faith in this place is manifold, both of there being a recompense, and of awaiting it, not under the same conditions, and of wrestling before the prizes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:39
verses.text: ) And the things also which concern Joseph are of Faith only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:40
verses.text: Joseph heard that [God] had made a promise to Abraham, that He had engaged His word "to thee and to thy seed will I give this land;" and though in a strange land, and not yet seeing the engagement fulfilled, but never faltered even so, but so believed as even to "speak of the Exodus, and to give commandment concerning his bones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:41
verses.text: He then not only believed himself, but led on the rest also to Faith: that having the Exodus always in mind (for he would not have "given commandment concerning his bones," unless he had been fully assured [of this]), they might look for their return [to Canaan].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:42
verses.text: Wherefore, when some men say, 'See! Even righteous men had care about their sepulchers,' let us reply to them, that it was for his reason: for he knew that "the earth is the Lord's and all that therein is".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:43
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:44
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:45
verses.text: ) He could not indeed have been ignorant of this, who lived in so great philosophy, who spent his whole life in Egypt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:46
verses.text: And yet if he had wished, it was possible for him to return, and not to mourn or vex himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:47
verses.text: But when he had taken up his father thither, why, did he enjoin them to carry up thence his own bones also? Evidently for this reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:48
verses.text: But what? Tell me, are not the bones of Moses himself laid in a strange land? And those of Aaron, of Daniel, of Jeremiah? And as to those of the Apostles we do not know where those of most of them are laid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:49
verses.text: For of Peter indeed, and Paul, and John, and Thomas, the sepulchers are well known; but those of the rest, being so many, have nowhere become known.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:50
verses.text: Let us not therefore lament at all about this, nor be so little-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:51
verses.text: For whereever we may be buried, "the earth is the Lord's and all that therein is".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:52
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:53
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:54
verses.text: ) Certainly what must take place, does take place: to mourn however, and lament, and bewail the departed, arises from littleness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:55
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:56
verses.text: ) "By faith, Moses when he was born, was hid three months of his parents".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:57
verses.text: Dost thou see that in this case they hoped for things on the earth after their death? And many things were fulfilled after their death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:58
verses.text: This is for some who say, 'After death those things were done for them, which they did not obtain while alive; nor did they believe [would be] after their death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:59
verses.text: '  Moreover Joseph did not say, He gave not the land to me in my life-time, nor to my father, nor to my grandfather, whose excellence too ought to have been reverenced; and will He vouchsafe to these wretched people what He did not vouchsafe to them? He said nothing of all this, but by Faith he both conquered and went beyond all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:60
verses.text: He has named Abel, Noah, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph, all illustrious and admirable men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:61
verses.text: Again he makes the encouragement greater, by bringing down the matter to ordinary persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:62
verses.text: For that the admirable should feel thus, is nothing wonderful, and to appear inferior to them, is not so dreadful: but to show oneself inferior even to people without names, this is the dreadful thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:63
verses.text: And he begins with the parents of Moses, obscure persons, who had nothing so great as their son [had].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:64
verses.text: Therefore also he goes on to increase the strangeness of what he says by enumerating even women that were harlots, and widows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:65
verses.text: For "by Faith" (he says) "the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not, when she had received the spies with peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:66
verses.text: And he mentions the rewards not only of belief but also of unbelief; as in [the case of] Noah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:67
verses.text: But at present we must speak of the parents of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:68
verses.text: Pharaoh gave orders that all the male children should be destroyed, and none had escaped the danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:69
verses.text: Whence did these expect to save their child? From faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:70
verses.text: What sort of Faith? "They saw" (he says) "that he was a proper child".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:71
verses.text: The very sight drew them on to Faith: thus from the beginning, yea from the very swaddling-clothes, great was the Grace that was poured out on that righteous man, this being not the work of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:72
verses.text: For observe, the child immediately on its birth appears fair and not disagreeable to the sight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:73
verses.text: Whose [work] was this? Not that of nature, but of the Grace of God, which also stirred up and strengthened that barbarian woman, the Egyptian, and took and drew her on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:74
verses.text: And yet in truth Faith had not a sufficient foundation in their case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:75
verses.text: For what was it to believe from sight? But you (he would say) believe from facts and have many pledges of Faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:76
verses.text: For "the receiving with joyfulness the spoiling of their goods" ( c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:77
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:78
verses.text: ), and other such [things], were [evidences] of Faith and of Patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:79
verses.text: But inasmuch as these [Hebrews] also had believed, and yet afterwards had become faint-hearted, he shows that the Faith of those [saints of old] also was long continued, as, for instance, that of Abraham, although the circumstances seemed to contend against it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:80
verses.text: "And" (he says) "they were not afraid of the king's commandment," although that was in operation, but this [their hope respecting their child] was simply a kind of bare expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:81
verses.text: And this indeed was [the act] of his parents; but Moses himself what did he contribute?   Next again an example appropriate to them, or rather greater than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:82
verses.text: For, saith he, ( ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:83
verses.text: – ) "by faith Moses when he was come to years, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter, choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season; esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt; for he had respect unto the recompense of the reward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:84
verses.text: As though he had said to them, 'No one of you has left a palace, yea a splendid palace, nor such treasures; nor, when he might have been a king's son, has he despised this, as Moses did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:85
verses.text: ' And that he did not simply leave [these things], he expressed by saying, "he refused," that is, he hated, he turned away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:86
verses.text: For when Heaven was set before him, it was superfluous to admire an Egyptian Palace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:87
verses.text: And see how admirably Paul has put it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:88
verses.text: He did not say, 'Esteeming heaven, and the things in heaven,' 'greater riches than the treasures of Egypt,' but what? "The reproach of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:89
verses.text: For the being reproached for the sake of Christ he accounted better than being thus at ease; and this itself by itself was reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:90
verses.text: "Choosing rather" (he says) "to suffer affliction with the people of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:91
verses.text: For ye indeed suffer on your own account, but he "chose" [to suffer] for others; and voluntarily threw himself into so many dangers, when it was in his power both to live religiously, and to enjoy good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:92
verses.text: "Than" (he says) "to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:93
verses.text: He called unwillingness "to suffer affliction with the" rest "sin": this, he says, [Moses] accounted to be "sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:94
verses.text: If then he accounted it "sin" not to be ready to "suffer affliction with" the rest, it follows that the suffering affliction must be a great good since he threw himself into it from the royal palace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:95
verses.text: But this he did, seeing some great things before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:96
verses.text: "Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:97
verses.text: What is, "the reproach of Christ"? It is being reproached in such ways as ye are, the reproach which Christ endured; Or that he endured for Christ's sake: for "that rock was Christ" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:98
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:99
verses.text: ); the being reproached as you are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:100
verses.text: But what is "the reproach of Christ"? That [because] we repudiate the [ways] of our fathers we are reproached; that we are evil-entreated when we have run to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:101
verses.text: It was likely that he also was reproached, when it was said to him, "Wilt thou kill me as thou killedst the Egyptian yesterday?" ( Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:102
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:103
verses.text: ) This is "the reproach of Christ," to be ill-treated to the end, and to the last breath: as He Himself was reproached and heard, "If Thou be the Son of God" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:104
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:105
verses.text: ), from those for whom He was crucified, from those who were of the same race.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:106
verses.text: This is "the reproach of Christ" when a man is reproached by those of his own family, or by those whom he is benefiting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:107
verses.text: For [Moses] also suffered these things from the man who had been benefited [by him].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:108
verses.text: In these words he encouraged them, by showing that even Christ suffered these things, and Moses also, two illustrious persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:109
verses.text: So that this is rather "the reproach of Christ" than of Moses inasmuch as He suffered these things from "His own".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:110
verses.text: ( John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:111
verses.text: ) But neither did the one send forth lightnings, nor the Other feel any [anger], but He was reviled and endured all things, whilst they "wagged their heads".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:112
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:113
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:114
verses.text: ) Since therefore it was probable that they [the readers] also would hear such things, and would long for the Recompense, he says that even Christ and Moses had suffered the like.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:115
verses.text: So then ease is [the portion] of sin; but to be reproached, of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:116
verses.text: For what then dost thou wish? "The reproach of Christ," or ease?   ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:117
verses.text: ) "By faith he forsook Egypt not fearing the wrath of the king; for he endured as seeing Him who is Invisible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:118
verses.text: What dost thou say? That he did not fear? And yet the Scripture says, that when he heard, he "was afraid" ( Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:119
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:120
verses.text: ), and for this cause provided for safety by flight, and stole away, and secretly withdrew himself; and afterwards he was exceedingly afraid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:121
verses.text: Observe the expressions with care: he said, "not fearing the wrath of the king," with reference to his even presenting himself again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:122
verses.text: For it would have been [the part] of one who was afraid, not to undertake again his championship, nor to have any hand in the matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:123
verses.text: That he did however again undertake it, was [the part] of one who committed all to God: for he did not say, 'He is seeking me, and is busy [in the search], and I cannot bear again to engage in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:124
verses.text: '  So that even flight was [an act of] faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:125
verses.text: Why then did he not remain (you say)? That he might not cast himself into a foreseen danger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:126
verses.text: For this finally would have been tempting [God]: to leap into the midst of dangers, and say, 'Let us see whether God will save me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:127
verses.text: ' And this the devil said to Christ, "Cast Thyself down".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:128
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:129
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:130
verses.text: ) Seest thou that it is a diabolical thing, to throw ourselves into danger without cause and for no purpose, and to try whether God will save us? For he [Moses] could no longer be their champion when they who were receiving benefits were so ungrateful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:131
verses.text: It would therefore have been a foolish and senseless thing to remain there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:132
verses.text: But all these things were done, because, "he endured as seeing Him who is Invisible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:133
verses.text: If then we too always see God with our mind, if we always think in remembrance of Him, all things will appear endurable to us, all things tolerable; we shall bear them all easily, we shall be above them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:134
verses.text: For if a person seeing one whom he loves, or rather, remembering him is roused in spirit, and elevated in thought, and bears all things easily, while he delights in the remembrance; one who has in mind Him who has vouchsafed to love us in deed, and remembers Him, when will he either feel anything painful, or dread anything fearful or dangerous? When will he be of cowardly spirit? Never.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:135
verses.text: For all things appear to us difficult, because we do not have the remembrance of God as we ought; because we do not carry Him about alway in our thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:136
verses.text: For surely He might justly say to us, "Thou hast forgotten Me, I also will forget thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:137
verses.text: And so the evil becomes twofold, both that we forget Him and He us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:138
verses.text: For these two things are involved in each other, yet are two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:139
verses.text: For great is the effect of God's remembrance, and great also of His being remembered by us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:140
verses.text: The result of the one is that we choose good things; of the other that we accomplish them, and bring them to their end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:141
verses.text: Therefore the prophet says, "I will remember Thee from the land of Jordan, and from the little hill of Hermon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:142
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:143
verses.text: xlii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:144
verses.text: ) The people which were in Babylon say this: being there, I will remember Thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:145
verses.text: Therefore let us also, as being in Babylon, [do the same].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:146
verses.text: For although we are not sitting among warlike foes, yet we are among enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:147
verses.text: For some [of them] indeed were sitting as captives, but others did not even feel their captivity, as Daniel, as the three children (cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:148
verses.text: Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:149
verses.text: cxxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:150
