verses.text: ); who even while they were in captivity became in that very country more glorious even than the king who had carried them captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:151
verses.text: And he who had taken them captive does obeisance to the captives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:152
verses.text: Dost thou see how great virtue is? When they were in actual captivity he waited on them as masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:153
verses.text: He therefore was the captive, rather than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:154
verses.text: It would not have been so marvelous if when they were in their native country, he had come and done them reverence in their own land, or if they had been rulers there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:155
verses.text: But the marvelous thing is, that after he had bound them, and taken them captive, and had them in his own country, he was not ashamed to do them reverence in the sight of all, and to "offer an oblation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:156
verses.text: ( Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:157
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:158
verses.text: )  Do you see that the really splendid things are those which relate to God, whereas human things are a shadow? He knew not, it seems, that he was leading away masters for himself, and that he cast into the furnace those whom he was about to worship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:159
verses.text: But to them, these things were as a dream.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:160
verses.text: Let us fear God, beloved, let us fear [Him]: even should we be in captivity, we are more glorious than all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:161
verses.text: Let the fear of God be present with us, and nothing will be grievous, even though thou speak of poverty, or of disease, or of captivity, or of slavery, or of any other grievous thing: Nay even these very things will themselves work together for us the other way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:162
verses.text: These men were captives, and the king worshiped them: Paul was a tent-maker, and they sacrificed to him as a God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:163
verses.text: Here a question arises: Why, you ask, did the Apostles prevent the sacrifices, and rend their clothes, and divert them from their attempt, and say with earnest lamentation, "What are ye doing? we also are men of like passions with you" ( Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:164
verses.text: ); whereas Daniel did nothing of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:165
verses.text: For that he also was humble, and referred [the] glory to God no less than they, is evident from many places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:166
verses.text: Especially indeed is it evident, from the very fact of his being beloved by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:167
verses.text: For if he had appropriated to himself the honor belonging to God, He would not have suffered him to live, much less to be in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:168
verses.text: Secondly, because even with great openness he said, "And as to me, O King, this secret hath not been revealed to me through any wisdom that is in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:169
verses.text: ( Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:170
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:171
verses.text: ) And again; he was in the den for God's sake, and when the prophet brought him food, he saith, "For God hath remembered me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:172
verses.text: ( Bel and the Dragon, ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:173
verses.text: ) Thus humble and contrite was he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:174
verses.text: He was in the den for God's sake, and yet he counted himself unworthy of His remembrance, and of being heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:175
verses.text: Yet we though daring [to commit] innumerable pollutions, and being of all men most polluted, if we be not heard at our first prayer, draw back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:176
verses.text: Truly, great is the distance between them and us, as great as between heaven and earth, or if there be any greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:177
verses.text: What sayest thou? After so many achievements, after the miracle which had been wrought in the den, dost thou account thyself so humble? Yea, he says; for what things soever we have done, "we are unprofitable servants".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:178
verses.text: ( Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:179
verses.text: ) Thus by anticipation did he fulfill the evangelical precept, and accounted himself nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:180
verses.text: For "God hath remembered me," he said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:181
verses.text: His prayer again, of how great lowliness of mind it is full.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:182
verses.text: And again the three children said thus, "We have sinned, we have committed iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:183
verses.text: ( Song of the Three Children, ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:184
verses.text: ) And everywhere they show their humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:185
verses.text: And yet Daniel had occasions innumerable for being puffed up; but he knew that these also came to him on account of his not being puffed up, and he did not destroy his treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:186
verses.text: For among all men, and in the whole world he was celebrated, not only because the king cast himself on his face and offered sacrifice to him, and accounted him to be a God, who was himself honored as God in all parts of the world: for he ruled over the whole [earth]; (and this is evident from Jeremiah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:187
verses.text: "Who putteth on the earth," saith he, "as a garment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:188
verses.text: (See Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:189
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:190
verses.text: and Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:191
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:192
verses.text: ) And again, "I have given it to Nebuchadnezzar My servant" ( Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:193
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:194
verses.text: ), and again from what he [the King] says in his letter).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:195
verses.text: And because he was held in admiration not only in the place where he was, but everywhere, and was greater than if the rest of the nations had been present and seen him; when even by letters [the King] confessed his submission and the miracle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:196
verses.text: But yet again for his wisdom he was also held in admiration, for it is said, "Art thou wiser than Daniel?" ( Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:197
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:198
verses.text: ) And after all these things he was thus humble, dying ten thousand times for the Lord's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:199
verses.text: Why then, you ask, being so humble did he not repel either the adoration which was paid him by the king, or the offerings?   This I will not say, for it is sufficient for me simply to mention the question, and the rest I leave to you, that at least in this way I may stir up your thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:200
verses.text: (This however I conjure you, to choose all things for the fear of God, having such examples; and because in truth we shall obtain the things here also, if we sincerely lay hold on the things which are to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:201
verses.text: ) For that he did not do this out of arrogance, is evident from his saying, "Thy gifts be to thyself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:202
verses.text: ( Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:203
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:204
verses.text: )  For besides this also again is another question, how while in words he rejected it, in deed he received the honor, and wore the chain [of gold].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:205
verses.text: ( Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:206
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:207
verses.text: )  Moreover while Herod on hearing the cry "It is the voice of a god and not of a man," inasmuch as "he gave not God the glory, burst in sunder, and all his bowels gushed out" ( Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:208
verses.text: , ; see i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:209
verses.text: ), this man received to himself even the honor belonging to God, not words only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:210
verses.text: However it is necessary to say what this is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:211
verses.text: In that case [at Lystra] the men were falling into greater idolatry, but in this [of Daniel] not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:212
verses.text: How? For his being thus accounted of, was an honor to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:213
verses.text: Therefore he said in anticipation, "And as to me, not through any wisdom that is in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:214
verses.text: ( Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:215
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:216
verses.text: ) And besides he does not even appear to have accepted the offerings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:217
verses.text: For he [the king] said (as it is written) that they should offer sacrifice, but it did not appear that the act followed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:218
verses.text: But there [at Lystra] they carried it even to sacrificing the bulls, and "they called" the one "Jupiter and" the other "Mercurius".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:219
verses.text: ( Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:220
verses.text: )  The chain [of gold] then he accepted, that he might make himself known; the offering however why does it not appear that he rejected it? For in the other case too they did not do it, but they attempted it, and the Apostles hindered them; wherefore here also he ought at once to have rejected [the adoration].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:221
verses.text: And there it was the entire people: here the King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:222
verses.text: Why he did not divert him [Daniel] expressed by anticipation, [viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:223
verses.text: ] that [the king] was not making an offering [to him] as to a God, to the overthrow of religious worship, but for the greater wonder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:224
verses.text: How so? It was on God's account that [Nebuchadnezzar] made the decree; wherefore [Daniel] did not mutilate the honor [offered].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:225
verses.text: But those others [at Lystra] did not act thus, but supposed them to be indeed gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:226
verses.text: On this account they were repelled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:227
verses.text: And here, after having done him reverence, he does these things: for he did not reverence him as a God, but as a wise man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:228
verses.text: But it is not clear that he made the offering: and even if he did make it, yet not that it was with Daniel's acceptance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:229
verses.text: And what [of this], that he called him "Belteshazzar, the name of" his own "god"? Thus [it seems] they accounted their gods to be nothing wonderful, when he called even the captive thus; he who commands all men to worship the image, manifold and of various colors, and who adores the dragon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:230
verses.text: Moreover the Babylonians were much more foolish than those at Lystra.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:231
verses.text: Wherefore it was not possible at once to lead them on to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:232
verses.text: And many [more] things one might say: but thus far these suffice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:233
verses.text: If therefore we wish to obtain all good things, let us seek the things of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:234
verses.text: For as they who seek the things of this world fail both of them and of the others, so they who prefer the things of God, obtain both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 27:235
verses.text: Let us then not seek these but those, that we may attain also to the good things promised in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:1
verses.text: Homily XXVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:2
verses.text: Hebrews xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:3
verses.text: –  "Through faith, he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood, lest he that destroyed the first-born should touch them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:4
verses.text: By faith they passed through the Red Sea, as by dry land; which the Egyptians assaying to do, were drowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:5
verses.text: By faith, the walls of Jericho fell down, after they had been compassed about seven days.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:6
verses.text: By faith, the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not, when she had received the spies with peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:7
verses.text: Paul is wont to establish many things incidently, and is very full of thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:8
verses.text: For such is the grace of The Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:9
verses.text: He does not comprehend a few ideas in a multitude of words, but includes great and manifold thought in brevity of expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:10
verses.text: Observe at least how, in the midst of exhortation, and when discoursing about faith, of what a type and mystery he reminds us, whereof we have the reality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:11
verses.text: "Through faith" (he says) "he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood, lest he that destroyed the first-born should touch them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:12
verses.text: But what is "the sprinkling of blood"? A lamb was slain in every household, and the blood was smeared on the door-posts, and this was a means of warding off the Egyptian destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:13
verses.text: If then the blood of a lamb preserved the Jews unhurt in the midst of the Egyptians, and under so great a destruction, much more will the blood of Christ save us, who have had it sprinkled not on the door-posts, but in our souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:14
verses.text: For even now also the Destroyer is going about in this depth of night: but let us be armed with that Sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:15
verses.text: (He calls the "sprinkling" anointing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:16
verses.text: ) For God has brought us out from Egypt, from darkness, from idolatry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:17
verses.text: Although what was done, was nothing, what was achieved was great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:18
verses.text: For what was done was blood; but was achieved, was salvation, and the stopping, and preventing of destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:19
verses.text: The angel feared the blood; for he knew of what it was a Type; he shuddered, thinking on the Lord's death; therefore he did not touch the door-posts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:20
verses.text: Moses said, Smear, and they smeared, and were confident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:21
verses.text: And you, having the Blood of the Lamb Himself, are ye not confident?   "By faith, they passed through the Red Sea as by dry land".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:22
verses.text: Again he compares one whole people with another, lest they should say, we cannot be as the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:23
verses.text: "By faith" (he says) "they passed through the Red Sea, as by dry land, which the Egyptians assaying to do, were drowned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:24
verses.text: Here he leads them also to a recollection of the sufferings in Egypt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:25
verses.text: How, "by faith"? Because they had hoped to pass through the sea, and therefore they prayed: or rather it was Moses who prayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:26
verses.text: Seest thou that everywhere Faith goes beyond human reasonings, and weakness and lowliness? Seest thou that at the same time they both believed, and feared punishment, both in the blood on the doors, and in the Red Sea?  And he made it clear that it was [really] water, through those that fell into it, and were choked; that it was not a mere appearance: but as in the case of the lions those who were devoured proved the reality of the facts, and in the case of the fiery furnace, those who were burnt; so here also thou seest that the same things become to the one a cause of salvation and glory, and to the other of destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:27
verses.text: So great a good is Faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:28
verses.text: And when we fall into perplexity, then are we delivered, even though we come to death itself, even though our condition be desperate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:29
verses.text: For what else was left [for them]? They were unarmed, compassed about by the Egyptians and the sea; and they must either be drowned if they fled, or fall into the hands of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:30
verses.text: But nevertheless [He] saved them from impossibilities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:31
verses.text: That which was spread under the one as land, overwhelmed the others as sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:32
verses.text: In the former case it forgot its nature: in the latter it even armed itself against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:33
verses.text: (Cf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:34
verses.text: Wisd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:35
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:36
verses.text: )   "By faith, the walls of Jericho fell down, after they had been compassed about for seven days".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:37
verses.text: For assuredly the sound of trumpets is not able to throw down stones, though one blow for ten thousand years; but Faith can do all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:38
verses.text: Seest thou that in all cases it is not by natural sequence, nor yet by any law of nature that it was changed, but all is done contrary to expectation? Accordingly in this case also all is done contrary to expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:39
verses.text: For inasmuch as he had said again and again, that we ought to trust to the future hopes, he introduced all this argument with reason, showing that not now [only], but even from the beginning all the miracles have been accomplished and achieved by means of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:40
verses.text: "By faith, the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not, having received the spies with peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:41
verses.text: It would then be disgraceful, if you should appear more faithless even than a harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:42
verses.text: Yet she [merely] heard what the men related, and forthwith believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:43
verses.text: Whereupon the end also followed; for when all perished, she alone was preserved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:44
verses.text: She did not say to herself, I shall be with my many friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:45
verses.text: She did not say, Can I possibly be wiser than these judicious men who do not believe,—and shall I believe? She said no such thing, but believed what had taken place, which it was likely that they would suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:46
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:47
verses.text: ) "And what shall I more say? For the time would fail me to tell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:48
verses.text: After this he no longer puts down the names: but having ended with an harlot, and put them to shame by the quality of the person, he no longer enlarges on the histories, lest he should be thought tedious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:49
verses.text: However he does not set them aside, but runs over them, [doing] both very judiciously, avoiding satiety, and not spoiling the closeness of arrangement; he was neither altogether silent, nor did he speak so as to annoy; for he effects both points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:50
verses.text: For when a man is contending vehemently [in argument], if he persist in contending, he wearies out the hearer, annoying him when he is already persuaded, and gaining the reputation of vain ambitiousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:51
verses.text: For he ought to accommodate himself to what is expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:52
verses.text: "And what do I more say" (he says)? "For the time would fail me to tell of Gideon, and of Barak, and of Samson, and of Jephthah, of David also and Samuel, and of the prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:53
verses.text: Some find fault with Paul, because he puts Barak, and Samson, and Jephthah in these places.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:54
verses.text: What sayest thou? After having introduced the harlot, shall he not introduce these? For do not tell me of the rest of their life, but only whether they did not believe and shine in Faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:55
verses.text: "And the prophets," he says, ( ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:56
verses.text: ) "who through faith subdued kingdoms".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:57
verses.text: Thou seest that he does not here testify to their life as being illustrious; for this was not the point in question: but the enquiry thus far was about their faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:58
verses.text: For tell me whether they did not accomplish all by faith?  "By faith," he says, "they subdued kingdoms;" those with Gideon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:59
verses.text: "Wrought righteousness;" who? The same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:60
verses.text: Plainly he means here, kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:61
verses.text: I think it is of David that he says "they obtained promises".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:62
verses.text: But of what sort were these? Those in which He said that his "seed should sit upon" his "throne".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:63
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:64
verses.text: cxxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:65
verses.text: )  "Stopped the mouths of lions," ( ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:66
verses.text: ) "quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:67
verses.text: See how they were in death itself, Daniel encompassed by the lions, the three children abiding in the furnace, the Israelites, Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, in divers temptations; and yet not even so did they despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:68
verses.text: For this is Faith; when things are turning out adversely, then we ought to believe that nothing adverse is done, but all things in due order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:69
verses.text: "Escaped the edge of the sword".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:70
verses.text: I think that he is again speaking of the three children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:71
verses.text: "Out of weakness were made strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:72
verses.text: Here he alludes to what took place at their return from Babylon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:73
verses.text: For "out of weakness," is out of captivity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:74
verses.text: When the condition of the Jews had now become desperate, when they were no better than dead bones, who could have expected that they would return from Babylon, and not return only; but also "wax valiant" and "turn to flight armies of aliens"? 'But to us,' some one says, 'no such thing has happened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:75
verses.text: ' But these are figures of "the things to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:76
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:77
verses.text: ) "Women received their dead raised to life again".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:78
verses.text: He here speaks of what occurred in regard to the prophets, Elisha, [and] Elijah; for they raised the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:79
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:80
verses.text: ) "And others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:81
verses.text: But we have not obtained a Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:82
verses.text: I am able however, he means, to show that they also were cut off, and did "not accept [deliverance], that they might obtain a better resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:83
verses.text: For why, tell me, when it was open to them to live, did they not choose it? Were they not evidently looking for a better life? And they who had raised up others, themselves chose to die; in order "to obtain a better resurrection," not such as the children of those women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:84
verses.text: Here I think he alludes both to John and to James.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:85
verses.text: For beheading is called "torturing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:86
verses.text: It was in their power still to behold the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:87
verses.text: It was in their power to abstain from reproving [sinners], and yet they chose to die; even they who had raised others chose to die themselves, "that they might obtain a better resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:88
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:89
verses.text: ) "And others had trial of cruel mockings and scourgings, yea moreover of bonds and imprisonment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:90
verses.text: He ends with these; with things that come nearer home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:91
verses.text: For these [ex amples] especially bring consolation, when the distress is from the same cause, since even if you mention something more extreme, yet unless it arise from the same cause, you have effected nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:92
verses.text: Therefore he concluded his discourse with this, mentioning "bonds, imprisonments, scourges, stonings," alluding to the case of Stephen, also to that of Zacharias.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:93
verses.text: Wherefore he added, "They were slain with the sword".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:94
verses.text: What sayest thou? Some "escaped the edge of the sword," and some "were slain by the sword".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:95
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:96
verses.text: ) What is this? Which dost thou praise? Which dost thou admire? The latter or the former? Nay, he says: the former indeed, is appropriate to you, and the latter, because Faith was strong even unto death itself, and it is a type of things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:97
verses.text: For the wonderful qualities of Faith are two, that it both accomplishes great things, and suffers great things, and counts itself to suffer nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:98
verses.text: And thou canst not say (he says) that these were sinners and worthless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:99
verses.text: For even if you put the whole world against them, I find that they weigh down the beam and are of greater value.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:100
verses.text: What then were they to receive in this life? Here he raises up their thoughts, teaching them not to be riveted to things present, but to mind things greater than all that are in this present life, since the "world is not worthy" of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:101
verses.text: What then dost thou wish to receive here? For it were an insult to thee, shouldst thou receive thy reward here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:102
verses.text: Let us not then mind worldly things, nor seek our recompense here, nor be so beggarly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:103
verses.text: For if "the" whole "world is not worthy of" them, why dost thou seek after a part of it? And with good reason; for they are friends of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:104
verses.text: Now by "the world" does he mean here the people, or the creation itself? Both: for the Scripture is wont to use the word of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:105
verses.text: If the whole creation, he would say, with the human beings that belong to it, were put in the balance, they yet would not be of equal value with these; and with reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:106
verses.text: For as ten thousand measures of chaff and hay would not be of equal value to ten pearls, so neither they; for "better is one that doeth the will of the Lord, than ten thousand transgressors" ( Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:107
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:108
verses.text: ); meaning by "ten thousand" not [merely] many, but an infinite multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:109
verses.text: Consider of how great value is the righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:110
verses.text: Joshua the son of Nun said, "Let the sun stand still at Gibeon, the moon at the valley of Elom" ( Josh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:111
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:112
verses.text: ), and it was so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:113
verses.text: Let then the whole world come, or rather two or three, or four, or ten, or twenty worlds, and let them say and do this; yet shall they not be able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:114
verses.text: But the friend of God commanded the creatures of his Friend, or rather he besought his Friend, and the servants yielded, and he below gave command to those above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:115
verses.text: Seest thou that these things are for service fulfilling their appointed course?  This was greater than the [miracles] of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:116
verses.text: Why (I ask)? Because it is not a like thing to command the sea and the heavenly [bodies].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:117
verses.text: For that indeed was also a great thing, yea very great, nevertheless it was not at all equal [to the other].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:118
verses.text: Why was this? The name of Joshua [Jesus], was a type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:119
verses.text: For this reason then, and because of the very name, the creation reverenced him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:120
verses.text: What then! Was no other person called Jesus? [Yes]; but this man was on this account so called in type; for he used to be called Hoshea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:121
verses.text: Therefore the name was changed: for it was a prediction and a prophecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:122
verses.text: He brought in the people into the promised land, as Jesus [does] into heaven; not the Law; since neither did Moses [bring them in], but remained without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:123
verses.text: The Law has not power to bring in, but grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:124
verses.text: Seest thou the types which have been before sketched out from the beginning? He laid his commands on the creation, or rather, on the chief part of the creation, on the very head itself as he stood below; that so when thou seest Jesus in the form of Man saying the same, thou mayest not be disturbed, nor think it strange.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:125
verses.text: He, even while Moses was living, turned back wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:126
verses.text: Thus, even while the Law is living, He directs all things; but not openly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:127
verses.text: But let us consider how great is the virtue of the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:128
verses.text: If here they work such things, if here they do such things, as the angels do, what then above? How great is the splendor they have?  Perhaps each of you might wish to be such as to be able to command the sun and moon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:129
verses.text: (At this point what would they say who assert that the heaven is a sphere? For why did he not [merely] say, "Let the sun stand still," but added "Let the sun stand still at the valley of Elom," that is, he will make the day longer? This was done also in the time of Hezekiah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:130
verses.text: The sun went back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:131
verses.text: This again is more wonderful than the other, to go the contrary way, not having yet gone round his course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:132
verses.text: )  We shall attain to greater things than these if we will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:133
verses.text: For what has Christ promised us? Not that we shall make the sun stand still, or the moon, nor that the sun shall retrace his steps, but what? "I and the Father will come unto him," He says, "and We will make our abode with him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:134
verses.text: ( John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:135
verses.text: ) What need have I of the sun and the moon, and of these wonders, when the Lord of all Himself comes down and abides with me? I need these not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:136
verses.text: For what need I any of these things? He Himself shall be to me for Sun and for Light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:137
verses.text: For, tell me, if thou hadst entered into a palace, which wouldst thou choose, to be able to rearrange some of the things which have been fixed there, or so to make the king a familiar friend, as to persuade him to take up his abode with thee? Much rather the latter than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:138
verses.text: But what wonder is it, says some one, that what a man commands, Christ should also? But Christ (you say) needs not the Father, but acts of His own authority, you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:139
verses.text: Well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:140
verses.text: Therefore first confess and say, that he needs not the Father, and acts of His own authority: and then I will ask thee, whether His prayer is not in the way of condescension and arrangement (for surely Christ was not inferior to Joshua the son of Nun), and that He might teach us? For as when thou hearest a teacher lisping, and saying over the alphabet, thou dost not say that he is ignorant; and when he asks, Where is such a letter? thou knowest that he does not ask in ignorance, but because he wishes to lead on the scholar; in like manner Christ also did not make His prayer as needing prayer, but desiring to lead thee on, that thou mayest continually apply thyself to prayer, that thou mayest do it without ceasing, soberly, and with great watchfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:141
verses.text: And by watching, I do not mean, merely the rising at night, but also the being sober in our prayers during the day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:142
verses.text: For such an one is called watchful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:143
verses.text: Since it is possible both in praying by night to be asleep, and in praying by day to be awake, when the soul is stretched out towards God, when it considers with whom it holds converse, to whom its words are addressed, when it has in mind that angels stand by with fear and trembling, while he approaches gaping and scratching himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:144
verses.text: Prayer is a mighty weapon if it be made with suitable mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:145
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn its strength, continued entreaty has overcome shamelessness, and injustice, and savage cruelty, and overbearing rashness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:146
verses.text: For He says, "Hear what the unjust judge saith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:147
verses.text: ( Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:148
verses.text: ) Again it has overcome sloth also, and what friendship did not effect, this continued entreaty did: and "although he will not give him because he is his friend" (He says), "yet because of his importunity he will rise and give to him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:149
verses.text: ( Luke xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:150
verses.text: ) And continued assiduity made her worthy who was unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:151
verses.text: "It is not meet" (He says) "to take the children's bread and to cast it to the dogs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:152
verses.text: Yea! Lord!" she says, "for even the dogs eat [the crumbs] from their master's table".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:153
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:154
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:156
verses.text: ) Let us apply ourselves to Prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:157
verses.text: It is a mighty weapon if it be offered with earnestness, if without vainglory, if with a sincere mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:158
verses.text: It has turned back wars, it has benefited an entire nation though undeserving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:159
verses.text: "I have heard their groaning" (He says) "and am come down to deliver them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:160
verses.text: ( Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:161
verses.text: ) It is itself a saving medicine, and has power to prevent sins, and to heal misdeeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:162
verses.text: In this the desolate widow was assiduous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:163
verses.text: (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:164
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:165
verses.text: )  If then we pray with humility, smiting our breast as the publican, if we utter what he did, if we say, "Be merciful to me a sinner" ( Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:166
verses.text: ), we shall obtain all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:167
verses.text: For though we be not publicans, yet have we other sins not less than his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:168
verses.text: For do not tell me, that thou hast gone wrong in some small matter [only], since the thing has the same nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:169
verses.text: For as a man is equally called a homicide whether he has killed a child or a man, so also is he called overreaching whether he be overreaching in much or in little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:170
verses.text: Yea and to remember injuries too, is no small matter, but even a great sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:171
verses.text: For it is said, "the ways of those who remember injuries [tend] to death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:172
verses.text: ( Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:173
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:174
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:175
verses.text: ) And "He that is angry with his brother without a cause, shall be in danger of hell," and he that "calleth his brother a fool" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:176
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:177
verses.text: ), and senseless, and numberless such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:178
verses.text: But we partake even of the tremendous mysteries unworthily, and we envy, and we revile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:179
verses.text: And some of us have even oftentimes been drunk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:180
verses.text: But each one of these things, even itself by itself, is enough to cast us out of the kingdom, and when they even come all together, what comfort shall we have? We need much penitence, beloved, much prayer, much endurance, much perseverance, that we may be enabled to attain the good things which have been promised to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:181
verses.text: Let us then say, even we, "Be merciful to me a sinner," nay rather, let us not say it only, but let us also be thus minded; and should another call us so, let us not be angry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:182
verses.text: He heard the words, "I am not as this Publican" ( Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:183
verses.text: ), and was not provoked thereby, but filled with compunction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:184
verses.text: He accepted the reproach, and he put away the reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:185
verses.text: The other spoke of the wound, and he sought the medicine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:186
verses.text: Let us say then, "Be merciful to me a sinner" ( Luke xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:187
verses.text: ); but even if another should so call us, let us not be indignant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:188
verses.text: But if we say ten thousand evil things of ourselves, and are vexed when we hear them from others, then there is no longer humility, nor confession, but ostentation and vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:189
verses.text: Is it ostentation (you say) to call one's self a sinner? Yes; for we obtain the credit of humility, we are admired, we are commended; whereas if we say the contrary of ourselves, we are despised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:190
verses.text: So that we do this too for the sake of credit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:191
verses.text: But what is humility? It is when another reviles us, to bear it, to acknowledge our fault, to endure evil speakings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:192
verses.text: And yet even this would not be [a mark] of humility but of candor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:193
verses.text: But now we call ourselves sinners, unworthy, and ten thousand other such names, but if another apply one of them to us, we are vexed, we become savage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:194
verses.text: Seest thou that this is not confession, nor even candor? Thou saidst of thyself that thou art such an one: be not indignant if thou hearest it also said by others, and art reproved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:195
verses.text: In this way thy sins are made lighter for thee, when others reproach thee: for they lay a burden on themselves indeed, but thee they lead onwards into philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:196
verses.text: Hear what the blessed David says, when Shimei cursed him, "Let him alone" (he says) "the Lord hath bidden him, that He might look on my humiliation" (he says): "And the Lord will requite me good for his cursing on this day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:197
verses.text: (  Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:198
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:200
verses.text: )  But thou while saying evil things of thyself, even in excess, if thou hearest not from others the commendations that are due to the most righteous, art enraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:201
verses.text: Seest thou that thou art trifling with things that are no subjects for trifling? For we even repudiate praises in our desire for other praises, that we may obtain yet higher panegyrics, that we may be more admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:202
verses.text: So that when we decline to accept commendations, we do it that we may augment them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:203
verses.text: And all things are done by us for credit, not for truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:204
verses.text: Therefore all things are hollow, all impracticable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 28:205
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech you now at any rate to withdraw from this mother of evils, vainglory, and to live according to what is approved by God, that so you may attain to the good things to come, in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father be glory, together with His Holy and good Spirit, now and ever and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:1
verses.text: Homily XXVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:2
verses.text: Hebrews xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:3
verses.text: ,  "They wandered about in sheep-skins, and goat-skins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented (of whom this world was not worthy); wandering in deserts, and in mountains, and in dens, and caves of the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:4
verses.text: At all times indeed, but especially then when I reflect upon the achievements of the saints, it comes over me to feel despondency concerning my own condition, because we have not even in dreams experienced the things among which those men spent their whole lives, not paying the penalty of sins, but always doing rightly and yet always afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:5
verses.text: For consider, I beseech you, Elijah, to whom our discourse has come round to-day, for he speaks of him in this passage, and in him his examples end: which [example] was appropriate to their case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:6
verses.text: And having spoken of what befell the Apostles, that "they were slain with the sword, were stoned," he goes back again to Elijah, who suffered the same things with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:7
verses.text: (See  Kings i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:8
verses.text: ) For since it was probable that they would not as yet hold the Apostles in so great estimation, he brings his exhortation and consolation from him who had been taken up [into Heaven] and who was held in special admiration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:9
verses.text: For "they wandered about" (he says) "in sheep-skins, and goat-skins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented, of whom this world was not worthy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:10
verses.text: They had not even raiment, he says, through the excess of affliction, no city, no house, no lodging-place; the same which Christ said, "but the Son of Man hath not where to lay His head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:11
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:12
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:13
verses.text: ) Why do I say "no lodging-place"? No standing-place: for not even when they had gained the wilderness, were they at rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:14
verses.text: For he said not, They sat down in the wilderness, but even when they were there, they fled, and were driven thence, not out of the inhabited world only, but even out of that which was uninhabitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:15
verses.text: And he reminds them of the places where they were set, and of things which there befell [them].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:16
verses.text: Then next, he says, they bring accusations against you for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:17
verses.text: What accusation had they against Elijah, when they drove him out, and persecuted him, and compelled him to struggle with famine? Which these [Hebrews] were then suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:18
verses.text: At least, the brethren, it is said, decided to send [relief] to those of the disciples who were afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:19
verses.text: "Every man according to his ability, determined to send relief unto the brethren that dwelt in Judea" ( Acts xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:20
verses.text: ), which was [the case] of these also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:21
verses.text: "Tormented" [or "ill-treated"], he says; that is, suffering distress, in journeyings, in dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:22
verses.text: But "They wandered about," what is this? "Wandering," he says, "in deserts and in mountains and in dens and caves of the earth," like exiles and outcasts, as persons taken in the basest [of crimes], as those not worthy to see the sun, they found no refuge from the wilderness, but must always be flying, must be seeking hiding-places, must bury themselves alive in the earth, always be in terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:23
verses.text: What then is the reward of so great a change? What is the recompense?  They have not yet received it, but are still waiting; and after thus dying in so great tribulation, they have not yet received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:24
verses.text: They gained their victory so many ages ago, and have not yet received [their reward].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:25
verses.text: And you who are yet in the conflict, are you vexed?  Do you also consider what a thing it is, and how great, that Abraham should be sitting, and the Apostle Paul, waiting till thou hast been perfected, that then they may be able to receive their reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:26
verses.text: For the Saviour has told them before that unless we also are present, He will not give it them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:27
verses.text: As an affectionate father might say to sons who were well approved, and had accomplished their work, that he would not give them to eat, unless their brethren came.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:28
verses.text: And art thou vexed, that thou hast not yet received the reward? What then shall Abel do, who was victor before all, and is sitting uncrowned? And what Noah? And what, they who lived in those [early] times: seeing that they wait for thee and those after thee?  Dost thou see that we have the advantage of them? For "God" (he says) "has provided some better thing for us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:29
verses.text: In order that they might not seem to have the advantage of us from being crowned before us, He appointed one time of crowning for all; and he that gained the victory so many years before, receives his crown with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:30
verses.text: Seest thou His tender carefulness?  And he did not say, "that they without us might not be crowned," but "that they without us might not be made perfect"; so that at that time they appear perfect also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:31
verses.text: They were before us as regards the conflicts, but are not before us as regards the crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:32
verses.text: He wronged not them, but He honored us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:33
verses.text: For they also wait for the brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:34
verses.text: For if we are "all one body," the pleasure becomes greater to this body, when it is crowned altogether, and not part by part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:35
verses.text: For the righteous are also worthy of admiration in this, that they rejoice in the welfare of their brethren, as in their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:36
verses.text: So that for themselves also, this is according to their wish, to be crowned along with their own members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:37
verses.text: To be glorified all together, is a great delight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:39
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:40
verses.text: ) "Wherefore" (he says) "we also being compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:41
verses.text: In many places the Scripture derives its consolation in evils from corresponding things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:42
verses.text: As when the prophet says, "From burning heat, and from storm, and rain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:43
verses.text: ( Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:44
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:45
verses.text: ) This at least he says here also, that the memory of those holy men, reestablishes and recovers the soul which had been weighed down by woes, as a cloud does him who is burnt by the too hot rays [of the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:46
verses.text: ]  And he did not say, "lifted on high above us," but, "compassing us about," which was more than the other; so that we are in greater security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:47
verses.text: What sort of "cloud"? "A load of witnesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:48
verses.text: With good reason he calls not those in the New [Testament] only, but those in the Old also, "witnesses" [or "martyrs"].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:49
verses.text: For they also were witnesses to the greatness of God, as for instance, the Three Children, those with Elijah, all the prophets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:50
verses.text: "Laying aside all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:51
verses.text: "All": what? That is, slumber, indifference, mean reasonings, all human things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:52
verses.text: "And the sin which doth [so] easily beset us"; εὐπερίστατον, that is either, "which easily circumvents us," or "what can easily be circumvented," but rather this latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:53
verses.text: For it is easy, if we will, to overcome sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:54
verses.text: "Let us run with patience" (he says) "the race that is set before us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:55
verses.text: He did not say, Let us contend as boxers, nor, Let us wrestle, nor, Let us do battle: but, what was lightest of all, the [contest] of the foot-race, this has he brought forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:56
verses.text: Nor yet did he say, Let us add to the length of the course; but, Let us continue patiently in this, let us not faint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:57
verses.text: "Let us run" (he says) "the race that is set before us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:58
verses.text: In the next place as the sum and substance of his exhortation, which he puts both first and last, even Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:59
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:60
verses.text: ) "Looking" (he says) "unto Jesus the Author and Finisher of our Faith"; The very thing which Christ Himself also continually said to His disciples, "If they have called the Master of the house Beelzebub, how much more them of His household?" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:61
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:62
verses.text: ) And again, "The disciple is not above his Master, nor the servant above his Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:63
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:64
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:65
verses.text: )  "Looking" (he says), that is, that we may learn to run.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:66
verses.text: For as in all arts and games, we impress the art upon our mind by looking to our masters, receiving certain rules through our sight, so here also, if we wish to run, and to learn to run well, let us look to Christ, even to Jesus "the author and finisher of our faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:67
verses.text: What is this? He has put the Faith within us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:68
verses.text: For He said to His disciples, "Ye have not chosen Me, but I have chosen you" ( John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:69
verses.text: ); and Paul too says, "But then shall I know, even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:70
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:71
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:72
verses.text: ) He put the Beginning into us, He will also put on the End.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:73
verses.text: "Who," he says, "for the joy that was set before Him, endured the Cross, despising the shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:74
verses.text: That is, it was in His power not to suffer at all, if He so willed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:75
verses.text: For "He did no sin, neither was guile found in His mouth" (  Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:76
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:77
verses.text: ); as He also says in the Gospels, "The Prince of the world cometh and hath nothing in Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:78
verses.text: ( John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:79
verses.text: ) It lay then in His power, if so He willed, not to come to the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:80
verses.text: For, "I have power," He says, "to lay down My life; and I have power to take it again".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:81
verses.text: ( John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:82
verses.text: ) If then He who was under no necessity of being crucified, was crucified for our sake, how much more is it right that we should endure all things nobly!  "Who for the joy that was set before Him" (he says) "endured the cross, despising the shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:83
verses.text: But what is, "Despising the shame"? He chose, he means, that ignominious death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:84
verses.text: For suppose that He died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:85
verses.text: Why [should He] also [die] ignominiously? For no other reason, but to teach us to make no account of glory from men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:86
verses.text: Therefore though under no obligation He chose it, teaching us to be bold against it, and to set it at nought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:87
verses.text: Why did he say not "pain," but "shame"? Because it was not with pain that He bore these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:88
verses.text: What then is the end? "He is set down at the right hand of the throne of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:89
verses.text: Seest thou the prize which Paul also says in an epistle, "Wherefore God also hath highly exalted Him, and given Him a Name which is above every name, that at the Name of Jesus Christ every knee should bow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:90
verses.text: ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:91
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:93
verses.text: ) He speaks in respect to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:94
verses.text: Well then, even if there were no prize, the example would suffice to persuade us to accept all [such] things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:95
verses.text: But now prizes also are set before us, and these no common ones, but great and unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:96
verses.text: Wherefore let us also, whenever we suffer anything of this kind, before the Apostles consider Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:97
verses.text: Why? His whole life was full of insults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:98
verses.text: For He continually heard Himself called mad, and a deceiver, and a sorcerer; and at one time the Jews said, "Nay," (it says) "but He deceiveth the people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:99
verses.text: ( John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:100
verses.text: ) And again, "That deceiver said while He was yet alive, after three days I will rise again".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:101
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:102
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:103
verses.text: ) As to sorcery too they calumniated Him, saying, "He casteth out the devils by Beelzebub".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:104
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:105
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:106
verses.text: ) And that "He is mad and hath a devil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:107
verses.text: ( John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:108
verses.text: ) "Said we not well" (it says) "that He hath a devil and is mad?" ( John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:109
verses.text: )  And these things He heard from them, when doing them good, performing miracles, showing forth the works of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:110
verses.text: For indeed, if He had been so spoken of, when He did nothing, it would not have been so wonderful: But [it is wonderful] that when He was teaching what pertained to Truth He was called "a deceiver," and when He cast out devils, was said to "have a devil," and when He was overthrowing all that was opposed [to God], was called a sorcerer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:111
verses.text: For these things they were continually alleging against Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:112
verses.text: And if thou wouldst know both the scoffs and the ironical jeerings, which they made against Him (what particularly wounds our souls), hear first those from His kindred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:113
verses.text: "Is not this" (it says) "the carpenter's son, whose father and mother we know? Are not his brethren all with us?" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:114
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:115
verses.text: ; Mark vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:116
verses.text: ; John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:117
verses.text: ) Also scoffing at Him from His country, they said He was "of Nazareth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:118
verses.text: And again, "search," it says, "and see, for out of Galilee hath no prophet arisen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:119
verses.text: ( John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:120
verses.text: ) And He endured being so greatly calumniated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:121
verses.text: And again they said, "Doth not the Scripture say, that Christ cometh from the town of Bethlehem?" ( John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:122
verses.text: )  Wouldst thou see also the ironical jeerings they made? Coming, it says, to the very cross they worshiped Him; and they struck Him and buffeted Him, and said, "Tell us who it is that smote Thee" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:123
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:124
verses.text: ); and they brought vinegar to Him, and said, "If Thou be the Son of God, come down from the Cross".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:125
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:126
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:127
verses.text: ) And again, the servant of the High Priest struck Him with the palm of his hand; and He says, "If I have spoken evil, bear witness of the evil; but if well, why smiteth thou Me?" ( John xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:128
verses.text: ) And in derision they put a robe about Him; and they spat in His face; and they were continually applying their tests, tempting Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:129
verses.text: Wouldest thou see also the accusations, some secret, some open, some from disciples? "Will ye also go away?" ( John vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:130
verses.text: ) He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:131
verses.text: And that saying, "Thou hast a devil" ( John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:132
verses.text: , vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:133
verses.text: ), was uttered by those who already believed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:134
verses.text: Was He not continually a fugitive, sometimes in Galilee, and sometimes in Judea? Was not His trial great, even from the swaddling clothes? When He was yet a young child, did not His mother take Him and go down into Egypt? For all these reasons he says, "Looking unto Jesus the Author and Finisher of our Faith who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:135
verses.text: To Him then let us look, also to the [sufferings] of His disciples, reading the [writings] of Paul, and hearing him say, "In much patience, in afflictions, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses, in stripes, in imprisonments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:136
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:137
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:139
verses.text: ) And again, "Even to this present hour, we both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buffeted, and have no certain dwelling-place, and labor, working with our own hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:140
verses.text: Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we suffer it; being defamed, we entreat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:141
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:142
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:144
verses.text: ) Has any one [of us] suffered the smallest part of these things? For, he says, [we are] "As deceivers, as dishonored, as having nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:145
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:146
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:148
verses.text: ) And again, "Of the Jews five times received I forty stripes save one; thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, a night and a day have I been in the deep; in journeyings often, in tribulations, in distress, in hunger".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:149
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:150
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:152
verses.text: ) And that these things seem good to God, hear him saying, "For this I besought the Lord thrice, and He said to me, My Grace is sufficient for thee; for My strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:153
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:154
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:156
verses.text: ) "Wherefore," he says, "I take pleasure in infirmities, in afflictions, in necessities, in distresses, in stripes, in imprisonments, that the power of Christ may rest upon me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:157
verses.text: Moreover, hear Christ Himself saying, "In the world ye shall have tribulation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:158
verses.text: ( John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:159
verses.text: )   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:160
verses.text: "For consider," saith he, "Him that endured such contradiction of sinners against Himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:161
verses.text: For if the sufferings of those near us arouse us, what earnestness will not those of our Master give us! What will they not work in us!  And passing by all [else], he expressed the whole by the [word] "Contradiction"; and by adding "such".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:162
verses.text: For the blows upon the cheek, the laughter, the insults, the reproaches, the mockeries, all these he indicated by "contradiction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:163
verses.text: And not these only, but also the things which befell Him during His whole life, of teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:164
verses.text: For a great, a truly great consolation are both the sufferings of Christ, and those of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:165
verses.text: For He so well knew that this is the better way of virtue, as even to go that way Himself, not having need thereof: He knew so well that tribulation is expedient for us, and that it becomes rather a foundation for repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:166
verses.text: For hear Him saying, "If a man take not his cross, and follow after Me, he is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:167
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:168
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:169
verses.text: ) If thou art a disciple, He means, imitate the Master; for this is [to be] a disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:170
verses.text: But if while He went by [the path of] affliction, thou [goest] by that of ease, thou no longer treadest the same path, which He trod, but another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:171
verses.text: How then dost thou follow, when thou followest not? How shalt thou be a disciple, not going after the Master? This Paul also says, "We are weak, but ye are strong; we are despised, but ye are honored".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:172
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:173
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:174
verses.text: ) How is it reasonable, he means, that we should be striving after opposite things, and yet that you should be disciples and we teachers?   Affliction then is a great thing, beloved, for it accomplishes two great things; It wipes out sins, and it makes men strong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:175
verses.text: What then, you say, if it overthrow and destroy? Affliction does not do this, but our own slothfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:176
verses.text: How (you say)? If we are sober and watchful, if we beseech God that He would not "suffer us to be tempted above that we are able" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:177
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:178
verses.text: ), if we always hold fast to Him, we shall stand nobly, and set ourselves against our enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:179
verses.text: So long as we have Him for our helper, though temptations blow more violently than all the winds, they will be to us as chaff and a leaf borne lightly along.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:180
verses.text: Hear Paul saying, "In all these things" (are his words) "we are more than conquerors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:181
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:182
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:183
verses.text: ) And again, "For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:184
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:185
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:186
verses.text: ) And again, "For the light affliction which is but for a moment, worketh for us a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:187
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:188
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:189
verses.text: )  Consider what great dangers, shipwrecks, afflictions one upon another, and other such things, he calls "light"; and emulate this inflexible one, who wore this body simply and heedlessly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:190
verses.text: Thou art in poverty? But not in such as Paul, who was tried by hunger, and thirst, and nakedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:191
verses.text: For he suffered this not for one day, but endured it continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:192
verses.text: Whence does this appear? Hear himself saying, "Even unto this present hour we both hunger and thirst and are naked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:193
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:194
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:195
verses.text: ) Oh! How great glory did he already have in preaching, when he was undergoing so great [afflictions]! Having now [reached] the twentieth year [thereof], at the time when he wrote this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:196
verses.text: For he says, "I knew a man fourteen years ago, whether in the body, or out of the body, I know not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:197
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:198
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:199
verses.text: ) And again, "After three years" (he says) "I went up to Jerusalem".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:200
verses.text: ( Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:201
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:202
verses.text: ) And again hear him saying, "It were better for me to die, than that any man should make my glorying void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:203
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:204
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:205
verses.text: ) And not only this, but again also in writing he said, "We are become as the filth of the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:206
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:207
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:208
verses.text: ) What is more difficult to endure than hunger? What than freezing cold? What than plottings made by brethren whom he afterwards calls "false brethren"? (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:209
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:210
verses.text: ) Was he not called the pest of the world? An Impostor? A subverter? Was he not cut with scourging?   These things let us take into our mind, beloved, let us consider them, let us hold them in remembrance, and then we shall never faint, though we be wronged, though we be plundered, though we suffer innumerable evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:211
verses.text: Let it be granted us to be approved in Heaven, and all things [are] endurable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:212
verses.text: Let it be granted us to fare well there, and things here are of no account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:213
verses.text: These things are a shadow, and a dream; whatever they may be, they are nothing either in nature or in duration, while those are hoped for and expected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:214
verses.text: For what wouldst thou that we should compare with those fearful things? What with the unquenchable fire? With the never-dying worm? Which of the things here canst thou name in comparison with the "gnashing of teeth," with the "chains," and the "outer darkness," with the "wrath," the "tribulation," the "anguish"? But as to duration? Why, what are ten thousand years to ages boundless and without end? Not so much as a little drop to the boundless ocean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:215
verses.text: But what about the good things? There, the superiority is still greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:216
verses.text: "Eye hath not seen," (it is said,) "ear hath not heard, neither have, entered into the heart of man" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:217
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:218
verses.text: ), and these things again shall be during boundless ages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:219
verses.text: For the sake of these then were it not well to be cut [by scourging] times out of number, to be slain, to be burned, to undergo ten thousand deaths, to endure everything whatsoever that is dreadful both in word and deed? For even if it were possible for one to live when burning in the fire, ought one not to endure all for the sake of attaining to those good things promised?   But why do I trifle in saying these things to men who do not even choose to disregard riches, but hold fast to them as though they were immortal? And if they give a little out of much, think they have done all? This is not Almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:220
verses.text: For Almsgiving is that of the Widow who emptied out "all her living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:221
verses.text: ( Mark xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:222
verses.text: ) But if thou dost not go on to contribute so much as the widow, yet at least contribute the whole of thy superfluity: keep what is sufficient, not what is superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:223
verses.text: But there is no one who contributes even his superabundance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:224
verses.text: For so long as thou hast many servants, and garments of silk, these things are all superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:225
verses.text: Nothing is indispensable or necessary, without which we are able to live; these things are superfluous, and are simply superadded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:226
verses.text: Let us then see, if you please, what we cannot live without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:227
verses.text: If we have only two servants, we can live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:228
verses.text: For whereas some live without servants, what excuse have we, if we are not content with two? We can also have a house built of brick of three rooms; and this were sufficient for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:229
verses.text: For are there not some with children and wife who have but one room? Let there be also, if you will, two serving boys.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:230
verses.text: And how is it not a shame (you say) that a gentlewoman should walk out with [only] two servants? It is no shame, that a gentlewoman should walk abroad with two servants, but it is a shame that she should go forth with many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:231
