verses.text: Perhaps you laugh when you hear this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:232
verses.text: Believe me it is a shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:233
verses.text: Do you think it a great matter to go out with many servants, like dealers in sheep, or dealers in slaves? This is pride and vainglory, the other is philosophy and respectability.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:234
verses.text: For a gentlewoman ought not to be known from the multitude of her attendants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:235
verses.text: For what virtue is it to have many slaves? This belongs not to the soul, and whatever is not of the soul does not show gentility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:236
verses.text: When she is content with a few things, then is she a gentlewoman indeed; but when she needs many, she is a servant and inferior to slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:237
verses.text: Tell me, do not the angels go to and fro about the world alone, and need not any one to follow them? Are they then on this account inferior to us? They who need no [attendants] to us who need them? If then not needing an attendant at all, is angelic, who comes nearer to the angelic life, she who needs many [attendants], or she who [needs] few? Is not this a shame? For a shame it is to do anything out of place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:238
verses.text: Tell me who attracts the attention of those who are in the public places, she who brings many in her train, or she who [brings but] few? And is not she who is alone, less conspicuous even than she who is attended by few? Seest thou that this [first-named conduct] is a shame? Who attracts the attention of those in the public places, she who wears beautiful garments, or she who is dressed simply and artlessly? Again who attracts those in the public places, she who is borne on mules, and with trappings ornamented with gold, or she who walks out simply, and as it may be, with propriety? Or we do not even look at this latter, if we even see her; but the multitudes not only force their way to see the other, but also ask, Who is she, and Where from? And I do not say how great envy is hereby produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:239
verses.text: What then (tell me), is it disgraceful to be looked at or not to be looked at? When is the shame greater, when all stare at her, or when no one [does]? When they inform themselves about her, or when they do not even care? Seest thou that we do everything, not for modesty's sake but for vainglory?  However, since it is impossible to draw you away from that, I am content for the present that you should learn that this [conduct] is no disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:240
verses.text: Sin alone is a disgrace, which no one thinks to be a disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:241
verses.text: Sin alone is a disgrace, which no one thinks to be a disgrace, but everything rather than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:242
verses.text: Let your dress be such as is needful, not superfluous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:243
verses.text: However, that we may not shut you up too narrowly, this I assure you, that we have no need of ornaments of gold, or of lace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:244
verses.text: And it is not I who say this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:245
verses.text: For that the words are not mine, hear the blessed Paul saying, and solemnly charging women "to adorn themselves, not with plaitings [of the hair], or gold, or pearls, or costly apparel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:246
verses.text: (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:247
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:248
verses.text: ) But with what kind, O Paul, wouldest thou tell us? For perhaps they will say, that only golden things are costly; and that silks are not costly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:249
verses.text: Tell us with what kind thou wouldest? "But having food and raiment, let us therewith" (he says) "be content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:250
verses.text: (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:251
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:252
verses.text: ) Let our garment be such as merely to cover us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:253
verses.text: For God hath given them to us for this reason, that we may cover our nakedness; and this any sort of garment can do, though but of trifling cost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:254
verses.text: Perhaps ye laugh, who wear dresses of silk; for in truth one may well laugh, considering what Paul enjoined and what we practice!  But my discourse is not addressed to women only, but also to men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:255
verses.text: For the rest of the things which we have are all superfluous; only the poor possess no superfluities; and perhaps they too from necessity: since, if it had been in their power, even they would not have abstained [from them].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:256
verses.text: Nevertheless, "whether in pretense or in truth" ( Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:257
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:258
verses.text: ), so far they have no superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:259
verses.text: Let us then wear such clothes as are sufficient for our need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:260
verses.text: For what does much gold mean? To those on the stage these things are fitting, this apparel belongs to them, to harlots, to those who do everything to be looked at.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:261
verses.text: Let her beautify herself, who is on the stage or the dancing platform.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:262
verses.text: For she wishes to attract all to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:263
verses.text: But a woman who professes godliness, let her not beautify herself thus, but in a different way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:264
verses.text: Thou hast a means of beautifying thyself far better than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:265
verses.text: Thou also hast a theater: for that theater make thyself beautiful: clothe thyself with those ornaments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:266
verses.text: What is thy theater? Heaven, the company of Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:267
verses.text: I speak not of Virgins only, but also of those in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:268
verses.text: All as many as believe in Christ have that theater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:269
verses.text: Let us speak such things that we may please those spectators.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:270
verses.text: Put on such garments that thou mayest gratify them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:271
verses.text: For tell me, if a harlot putting aside her golden ornaments, and her robes, and her laughter, and her witty and unchaste talk, clothe herself with a cheap garment, and having dressed herself simply come [on the stage], and utter religious words, and discourse of chastity, and say nothing indelicate, will not all rise up? Will not this theater be dispersed? Will they not cast her out, as one who does not know how to suit herself to the crowd, and speaks things foreign to that Satanic theater? So thou also, if thou enter into the Theater of Heaven clad with her garments, the spectators will cast thee out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:272
verses.text: For there, there is no need of these garments of gold, but of different ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:273
verses.text: Of what kind? Of such as the prophet names, "clothed in fringed work of gold, and in varied colors" ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:274
verses.text: xlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:275
verses.text: ), not so as to make the body white and glistering, but so as to beautify the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:276
verses.text: For the soul it is, which is contending and wrestling in that Theater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:277
verses.text: "All the glory of the King's daughter is from within" ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:278
verses.text: xlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:279
verses.text: ), it says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:280
verses.text: With these do thou clothe thyself; for [so] thou both deliverest thyself from other evils innumerable, and thy husband from anxiety and thyself from care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:281
verses.text: For so thou wilt be respected by thy husband, when thou needest not many things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:282
verses.text: For every man is wont to be shy towards those who make requests of him; but when he sees that they have no need of him, then he lets down his pride, and converses with them as equals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:283
verses.text: When thy husband sees that thou hast no need of him in anything, that thou thinkest lightly of the presents which come from him, then, even though he be very arrogant, he will respect thee more, than if thou wert clad in golden ornaments; and thou wilt no longer be his slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:284
verses.text: For those of whom we stand in need, we are compelled to stoop to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:285
verses.text: But if we restrain ourselves we shall no longer be regarded as criminals, but he knows that we pay him obedience from the fear of God, not for what is given by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:286
verses.text: For now, when that he confers great favors on us, whatever honor he receives, he thinks he has not received all [that is due to him]: but then, though he obtain but a little, he will account it a favor he does not reproach, nor will he be himself compelled to overreach on thy account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:287
verses.text: For what is more unreasonable, than to provide golden ornaments, to be worn in baths, and in market places? However, in baths and in market places it is perhaps no wonder, but that a woman should come into Church so decked out is very ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:288
verses.text: For, for what possible reason does she come in here wearing golden ornaments, she who ought to come in that she may hear [the precept] "that they adorn not themselves with gold, nor pearls, nor costly array"? (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:289
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:290
verses.text: ) With what object then, O woman, dost thou come? Is it indeed to fight with Paul, and show that even if he repeat these things ten thousand times thou regardest them not? Or is it as wishing to put us your teachers to shame as discoursing on these subjects in vain? For tell me; if any heathen and unbeliever, after he has heard the passage read where the blessed Paul says these things, having a believing wife, sees that she makes much account of beautifying herself, and puts on ornaments of gold, that she may come into Church and hear Paul charging [the women] that they adorn themselves, neither with "gold" (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:291
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:292
verses.text: ), nor with "pearls," nor with "costly array," will he not indeed say to himself, when he sees her in her little room, putting on these things, and arranging them beautifully, "Why is my wife staying within in her little room? Why is she so slow? Why is she putting on her golden ornaments? Where has she to go to? Into the Church? For what purpose? To hear? 'not with costly array';" will he not smile, will he not burst out into laughter? will he not think our religion a mockery and a deceit? Wherefore, I beseech [you], let us leave golden ornaments to processions, to theaters, to signs on the shops.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:293
verses.text: But let not the image of God be decked out with these things: let the gentlewoman be adorned with gentility, and gentility is the absence of pride, and of boastful display.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:294
verses.text: Nay even if thou wish to obtain glory from men, thou wilt obtain it thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:295
verses.text: For we shall not wonder so much that the wife of a rich man wears gold and silk (for this is the common practice of them all), as when she is dressed in a plain and simple garment made merely of wool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:296
verses.text: This all will admire, this they will applaud.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:297
verses.text: For in that adorning indeed of ornaments of gold and of costly apparel, she has many to share with her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:298
verses.text: And if she surpass one, she is surpassed by another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:299
verses.text: Yea, even if she surpass all, she must yield the palm to the Empress herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:300
verses.text: But in the other case, she outdoes all, even the Emperor's wife herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:301
verses.text: For she alone in wealth, has chosen the [dress] of the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:302
verses.text: So that even if we desire glory, here too the glory is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:303
verses.text: I say this not only to widows, and to the rich; for here the necessity of widowhood seems to cause this: but to those also who have a husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:304
verses.text: But, you say, I do not please my husband [if I dress plainly].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:305
verses.text: It is not thy husband thou wishest to please, but the multitude of poor women; or rather not to please them, but to make them pine [with envy], and to give them pain, and make their poverty greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:306
verses.text: How many blasphemies are uttered because of thee! 'Let there be no poverty' (say they).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:307
verses.text: 'God hates the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:308
verses.text: ' 'God loves not those in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:309
verses.text: ' For that it is not thy husband whom thou wishest to please, and for this reason thou deckest thyself out, thou makest plain to all by what thou thyself doest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:310
verses.text: For as soon as thou hast passed over the threshold of thy chamber, thou immediately puttest off all, both the robes, and the golden ornaments, and the pearls; and at home of all places thou dost not wear them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:311
verses.text: But if thou really wishest to please thy husband, there are ways of pleasing him, by gentleness, by meekness, by propriety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:312
verses.text: For believe me, O woman, even if thy husband be infinitely debased, these are the things which will more effectually win him, gentleness, propriety, freedom from pride and expensiveness and extravagance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:313
verses.text: For even if thou devise ten thousand such things, thou wilt not restrain the profligate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:314
verses.text: And this they know who have had such husbands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:315
verses.text: For however thou mayest beautify thyself, he being a profligate will go off to a courtesan; while [the husband] that is chaste and regular thou wilt gain not by these means, but by the opposite: yea by these thou even causest him pain, clothing thyself with the reputation of a lover of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:316
verses.text: For what if thy husband out of respect, and that as a sober-minded man, does not speak, yet inwardly he will condemn thee, and will not conceal ill-will and jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:317
verses.text: Wilt thou not drive away all pleasure for the future, by exciting ill-will against thyself?   Possibly you are annoyed at hearing what is said, and are indignant, saying, 'He irritates husbands still more against their wives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:318
verses.text: ' I say this, not to irritate your husbands, but I wish that these things should be done by you willingly, for your own sakes, not for theirs; not to free them from envy but to free you from the parade of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:319
verses.text: Dost thou wish to appear beautiful? I also wish it, but with beauty which God seeks, which "the King desires".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:320
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:321
verses.text: xlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:322
verses.text: ) Whom wouldst thou have as a Lover? God or men? Shouldest thou be beautiful with that beauty, God will "desire thy beauty"; but if with the other apart from this, He will abominate thee, and thy lovers will be profligates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:323
verses.text: For no man who loves a married woman is good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:324
verses.text: Consider this even in regard to the adorning that is external.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:325
verses.text: For the other adorning, I mean that of the soul, attracts God; but this again, profligates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:326
verses.text: Seest thou that I care for you, that I am anxious for you, that ye may be beautiful, really beautiful, splendid, really splendid, that instead of profligate men, ye may have for your Lover God the Lord of all? And she who has Him for her Lover, to whom will she be like? She has her place among the choirs of Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:327
verses.text: For if one who is beloved of a king is accounted happy above all, what will her dignity be who is beloved of God with much love? Though thou put the whole world [in the balance against it], there is nothing equivalent to that beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:328
verses.text: This beauty then let us cultivate; with these embellishments let us adorn ourselves, that we may pass into the Heavens, into the spiritual chambers, into the nuptial chamber that is undefiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:329
verses.text: For this beauty is liable to be destroyed by anything; and when it lasts well, and neither disease nor anxiety impair it (which is impossible), it does not last twenty years.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:330
verses.text: But the other is ever blooming, ever in its prime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:331
verses.text: There, there is no change to fear; no old age coming brings a wrinkle, no undermining disease withers it; no desponding anxiety disfigures it; but it is far above all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:332
verses.text: But this [earthly beauty] takes flight before it appears, and if it appears it has not many admirers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:333
verses.text: For those of well-ordered minds do not admire it; and those who do admire it, admire with wantonness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:334
verses.text: Let us not therefore cultivate this [beauty], but the other: let us have that, so that with bright torches we may pass into the bridal chamber.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:335
verses.text: For not to virgins only has this been promised, but to virgin souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:336
verses.text: For had it belonged merely to virgins, those five would not have been shut out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:337
verses.text: This then belongs to all who are virgins in soul, who are freed from worldly imaginations: for these imaginations corrupt our souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:338
verses.text: If therefore we remain unpolluted, we shall depart thither, and shall be accepted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:339
verses.text: "For I have espoused you," he says, "to one husband, to present you a chaste virgin unto Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:340
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:341
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:342
verses.text: ) These things he said, not with reference to Virgins, but to the whole body of the entire Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:343
verses.text: For the uncorrupt soul is a virgin, though she have a husband: she is a virgin as to that which is Virginity indeed, that which is worthy of admiration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:344
verses.text: For this of the body is but the accompaniment and shadow of the other: while that is the True Virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:345
verses.text: This let us cultivate, and so shall we be able with cheerful countenance to behold the Bridegroom, to enter in with bright torches, if the oil do not fail us, if by melting down our golden ornaments we procure such oil as makes our lamps bright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:346
verses.text: And this oil is lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:347
verses.text: If we impart what we have to others, if we make oil therefrom, then it will protect us, and we shall not say at that time, "Give us oil, for our lamps are going out" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:348
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:349
verses.text: ), nor shall we beg of others, nor shall we be shut out when we are gone to them that sell, nor shall we hear that fearful and terrible voice, while we are knocking at the doors, "I know you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:350
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:351
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:352
verses.text: ) But He will acknowledge us, and we shall go in with the Bridegroom, and having entered into the spiritual Bride-chamber we shall enjoy good things innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:353
verses.text: For if here the bride-chamber is so bright, the rooms so splendid, that none is weary of observing them, much more there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:354
verses.text: Heaven is the chamber, and the bride-chamber better than Heaven; then we shall enter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:355
verses.text: But if the Bride-chamber is so beautiful, what will the Bridegroom be?  And why do I say, 'Let us put away our golden ornaments, and give to the needy'? For if ye ought even to sell yourselves, if ye ought to become slaves instead of free women, that so ye might be able to be with that Bridegroom, to enjoy that Beauty, [nay] merely to look on that Countenance, ought you not with ready mind to welcome all things? We look at and admire a king upon the earth, but when [we see] a king and a bridegroom both, much more ought we to welcome him with readiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:356
verses.text: Truly these things are a shadow, while those are a reality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:357
verses.text: And a King and a Bridegroom in Heaven! To be counted worthy also to go before Him with torches, and to be near Him, and to be ever with Him, what ought we not to do? What should we not perform? What should we not endure? I entreat you, let us conceive some desire for those blessings, let us long for that Bridegroom, let us be virgins as to the true Virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:358
verses.text: For the Lord seeks after the virginity of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:359
verses.text: With this let us enter into Heaven, "not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing" ( Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:360
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 29:361
verses.text: ); that we may attain also to the good things promised, of which may we all be partakers through the grace and mercy of Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:1
verses.text: Homily XXIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:2
verses.text: Hebrews xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:3
verses.text: –  "Ye have not yet resisted unto blood, striving against sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:4
verses.text: And ye have forgotten the exhortation which speaketh unto you as unto children, My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:5
verses.text: For whom the Lord loveth, He chasteneth: and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:6
verses.text: There are two kinds of consolation, apparently opposed to one another, but yet contributing great strength each to the other; both of which he has here put forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:7
verses.text: The one is when we say that persons have suffered much: for the soul is refreshed, when it has many witnesses of its own sufferings, and this he introduced above, saying, "Call to mind the former days, in which after ye had been illuminated ye endured a great fight of afflictions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:9
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:10
verses.text: ) The other is when we say, "Thou hast suffered no great thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:11
verses.text: The former, when [the soul] has been exhausted refreshes it, and makes it recover breath: the latter, when it has become indolent and supine, turns it again and pulls down pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:12
verses.text: Thus that no pride may spring up in them from that testimony [to their sufferings], see what he does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:13
verses.text: "Ye have not yet" (he says) "resisted unto blood, [striving] against sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:14
verses.text: And he did not at once go on with what follows, but after having shown them all those who had stood "unto blood," and then brought in the glory of Christ, His sufferings, he afterwards easily pursued his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:15
verses.text: This he says also in writing to the Corinthians, "There hath no temptation taken you, but such as is common to man" (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:16
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:17
verses.text: ), that is, small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:18
verses.text: For this is enough to arouse and set right the soul, when it considers that it has not risen to the whole [trial], and encourages itself from what has already befallen it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:19
verses.text: What he means is this: Ye have not yet submitted to death; your loss has extended to money, to reputation, to being driven from place to place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:20
verses.text: Christ however shed His blood for you, while you have not [done it] for yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:21
verses.text: He contended for the Truth even unto death fighting for you; while ye have not yet entered upon dangers that threaten death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:22
verses.text: "And ye have forgotten the exhortation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:23
verses.text: That is, And ye have slackened your hands, ye have become faint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:24
verses.text: "Ye have not yet," he said, "resisted unto blood, striving against sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:25
verses.text: Here he indicates that sin is both very vigorous, and is itself armed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:26
verses.text: For the [expression] "Ye have resisted [stood firm against]," is used with reference to those who stand firm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:27
verses.text: "Which" (he says) "speaketh unto you as unto sons, My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:28
verses.text: He has drawn his encouragement from the facts themselves; over and above he adds also that which is drawn from arguments, from this testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:29
verses.text: "Faint not" (he says) "when thou art rebuked of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:30
verses.text: It follows that these things are of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:31
verses.text: For this too is no small matter of consolation, when we learn that it is God's work that such things have power, He allowing [them]; even as also Paul says; "He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for My strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:32
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:33
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:34
verses.text: ) He it is who allows [them].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:35
verses.text: "For whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:36
verses.text: Thou canst not say that any righteous man is without affliction: even if he appear to be so, yet we know not his other afflictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:37
verses.text: So that of necessity every righteous man must pass through affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:38
verses.text: For it is a declaration of Christ, that the wide and broad way leads to destruction, but the strait and narrow one to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:39
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:40
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:42
verses.text: ) If then it is possible to enter into life by that means, and is not by any other, then all have entered in by the narrow [way], as many as have departed unto life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:43
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:44
verses.text: "Ye endure chastisement" (he says); not for punishment, nor for vengeance, nor for suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:45
verses.text: See, from that from which they supposed they had been deserted [of God], from these he says they may be confident, that they have not been deserted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:46
verses.text: It is as if he had said, Because ye have suffered so many evils, do you suppose that God has left you and hates you? If ye did not suffer, then it were right to suppose this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:47
verses.text: For if "He scourgeth every son whom He receiveth," he who is not scourged, perhaps is not a son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:48
verses.text: What then, you say, do not bad men suffer distress? They suffer indeed; how then? He did not say, Every one who is scourged is a son, but every son is scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:49
verses.text: For in all cases He scourges His son: what is wanted then is to show, whether any son is not scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:50
verses.text: But thou wouldest not be able to say: there are many wicked men also who are scourged, such as murderers, robbers, sorcerers, plunderers of tombs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:51
verses.text: These however are paying the penalty of their own wickedness, and are not scourged as sons, but punished as wicked: but ye as sons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:52
verses.text: Then again [he argues] from the general custom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:53
verses.text: Seest thou how he brings up arguments from all quarters, from facts in the Scripture, from its words, from our own notions, from examples in ordinary life? ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:54
verses.text: ) "But if ye be without chastisement" [&c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:56
verses.text: Seest thou that he said what I just mentioned, that it is not possible to be a son without being chastened? For as in families, fathers care not for bastards, though they learn nothing, though they be not distinguished, but fear for their legitimate sons lest they should be indolent, [so here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:58
verses.text: If then not to be chastised is [a mark] of bastards, we ought to rejoice at chastisement, if this be [a sign] of legitimacy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:59
verses.text: "God dealeth with you as with sons"; for this very cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:61
verses.text: "Furthermore, we have had fathers of our flesh which corrected us, and we gave them reverence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:62
verses.text: Again, [he reasons] from their own experiences, from what they themselves suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:63
verses.text: For as he says above, "Call to mind the former days" ( c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:64
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:65
verses.text: ), so here also "God" (he saith) "dealeth with you as with sons," and ye could not say, We cannot bear it: yea, "as with sons" tenderly beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:66
verses.text: For if they reverence their "fathers of the flesh," how shall not you reverence your heavenly Father?  However the difference arises not from this alone, nor from the persons, but also from the cause itself, and from the fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:67
verses.text: For it is not on the same grounds that He and they inflict chastisement: but they [did it] with a view to "what seemed good to them," that is, fulfilling [their own] pleasure oftentimes, and not always looking to what was expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:68
verses.text: But here, that cannot be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:69
verses.text: For He does this not for any interest of His own but for you, and for your benefit alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:70
verses.text: They [did it] that ye might be useful to themselves also, oftentimes without reason; but here there is nothing of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:71
verses.text: Seest thou that this also brings consolation? For we are most closely attached to those [earthly parents], when we see that not for any interests of their own they either command or advise us: but their earnestness is, wholly and solely, on our account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:72
verses.text: For this is genuine love, and love in reality, when we are beloved though we be of no use to him who loves us,—not that he may receive, but that he may impart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:73
verses.text: He chastens, He does everything, He uses all diligence, that we may become capable of receiving His benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:74
verses.text: ( Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:75
verses.text: ) "For they verily" (he says) "for a few days chastened us after their own pleasure, but He for our profit, that we might be partakers of His holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:76
verses.text: What is "of his holiness"? It is, of His purity, so as to become worthy of Him, according to our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:77
verses.text: He earnestly desires that ye may receive, and He does all that He may give you: do ye not earnestly endeavor that ye may receive? "I said unto the Lord" (one says) "Thou art my Lord, for of my good things Thou hast no need".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:78
verses.text: ( Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:79
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:80
verses.text: )  "Furthermore," he saith, "we have had fathers of our flesh which corrected us and we gave them reverence: shall we not much rather be in subjection to the Father of spirits, and live?" ("To the Father of spirits," whether of spiritual gifts, or of prayers, or of the incorporeal powers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:81
verses.text: ) If we die thus, then "we shall live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:82
verses.text: For they indeed for a few days chastened us after their own pleasure," for what seems [so] is not always profitable, but "He for our profit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:83
verses.text: Therefore chastisement is "profitable"; therefore chastisement is a "participation of holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:84
verses.text: Yea and this greatly: for when it casts out sloth, and evil desire, and love of the things of this life, when it helps the soul, when it causes a light esteem of all things here (for affliction [does] this), is it not holy? Does it not draw down the grace of the Spirit?  Let us consider the righteous, from what cause they all shone brightly forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:85
verses.text: Was it not from affliction? And, if you will, let us enumerate them from the first and from the very beginning: Abel, Noah himself; for it is not possible that he, being the only one in that so great multitude of the wicked, should not have been afflicted; for it is said, "Noah being" alone "perfect in his generation, pleased God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:86
verses.text: ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:87
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:88
verses.text: ) For consider, I beseech you, if now, when we have innumerable persons whose virtue we may emulate, fathers, and children, and teachers, we are thus distressed, what must we suppose he suffered, alone among so many? But should I speak of the circumstances of that strange and wonderful rain? Or should I speak of Abraham, his wanderings one upon another, the carrying away of his wife, the dangers, the wars, the famines? Should I speak of Isaac, what fearful things he underwent, driven from every place, and laboring in vain, and toiling for others? Or of Jacob? for indeed to enumerate all his [afflictions] is not necessary, but it is reasonable to bring forward the testimony, which he himself [gave] when speaking with Pharaoh; "Few and evil are my days, and they have not attained to the days of my fathers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:89
verses.text: ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:90
verses.text: xlvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:91
verses.text: ) Or should I speak of Joseph himself? Or of Moses? Or of Joshua? Or of David? Or of Elijah? Or of Samuel? Or wouldest thou [that I speak] of all the prophets? Wilt thou not find that all these were made illustrious from their afflictions? Tell me then, dost thou desire to become illustrious from ease and luxury? But thou canst not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:92
verses.text: Or should I speak of the Apostles? Nay but they went beyond all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:93
verses.text: And Christ said this, "In the world ye shall have tribulation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:94
verses.text: ( John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:95
verses.text: ) And again, "Ye shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:96
verses.text: ( John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:97
verses.text: ) And, that "Strait and narrow is the way that leadeth unto life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:98
verses.text: ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:99
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:100
verses.text: ) The Lord of the way said, that it is "narrow and strait"; and dost thou seek the "broad" [way]? How is this not unreasonable? In consequence thou wilt not arrive at life, going another [way], but at destruction, for thou hast chosen the [path] which leads thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:101
verses.text: Wouldst thou that I bring before you those [that live] in luxury? Let us ascend from the last to the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:102
verses.text: The rich man who is burning in the furnace; the Jews who live for the belly, "whose god is their belly" ( Phil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:103
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:104
verses.text: ), who were ever seeking ease in the wilderness, were destroyed; as also those in Sodom, on account of their gluttony; and those in the time of Noah, was it not because they chose this soft and dissolute life? For "they luxuriated," it says, "in fullness of bread".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:105
verses.text: ( Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:106
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:107
verses.text: ) It speaks of those in Sodom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:108
verses.text: But if "fullness of bread" wrought so great evil, what should we say of other delicacies? Esau, was not he in ease? And what of those who being of "the sons of God" ( Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:109
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:110
verses.text: ), looked on women, and were borne down the precipice? And what of those who were maddened by inordinate lust? and all the kings of the nations, of the Babylonians, of the Egyptians, did they not perish miserably? Are they not in torment?   And as to things now, tell me, are they not the same? Hear Christ saying, "They that wear soft clothing are in kings' houses" ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:111
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:112
verses.text: ), but they who do not [wear] such things, are in Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:113
verses.text: For the soft garment relaxes even the austere soul, breaks it and enervates it: yea, even if it meet with a body rough and hard, it speedily by such delicate treatment makes it soft and weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:114
verses.text: For, tell me, for what other reason do you suppose women are so weak? Is it from their sex only? By no means: but from their way of living, and their bringing up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:115
verses.text: For their avoiding exposure, their inactivity, their baths, their unguents, their multitude of perfumes, the delicate softness of their couches, makes them in the end such as they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:116
verses.text: And that thou mayest understand, attend to what I say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:117
verses.text: Tell me; take from a garden a tree from those standing in the uncultivated part and beaten by the winds, and plant it in a moist and shady place, and thou wilt find it very unworthy of that from which thou didst originally take it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:118
verses.text: And that this is true, [appears from the fact that] women brought up in the country are stronger than citizens of towns: and they would overcome many such in wrestling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:119
verses.text: For when the body becomes more effeminate, of necessity the soul also shares the mischief, since, for the most part, its energies are affected in accordance with the [body].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:120
verses.text: For in illness we are different persons owing to weakness, and when we become well, we are different again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:121
verses.text: For as in the case of a string when the tones are weak and relaxed, and not well arranged, the excellence of the art is also destroyed, being obliged to serve the ill condition of the strings: so in the case of the body also, the soul receives from it many hurts, many necessities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:122
verses.text: For when it needs much nursing, the other endures a bitter servitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:123
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, let us make it strong by work, and not nurse it as an invalid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:124
verses.text: My discourse is not to men only but to women also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:125
verses.text: For why dost thou, O woman, continually enfeeble [thy body] with luxury and exhaust it? Why dost thou ruin thy strength with fat? This fat is flabbiness, not strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:126
verses.text: Whereas, if thou break off from these things, and manage thyself differently, then will thy personal beauty also improve according to thy wish, when strength and a good habit of body are there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:127
verses.text: If however thou beset it with ten thousand diseases, there will neither be bloom of complexion, nor good health; for thou wilt always be in low spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:128
verses.text: And you know that as when the air is smiling it makes a beautiful house look splendid, so also cheerfulness of mind when added to a fair countenance, makes it better: but if [a woman] is in low spirits and in pain she becomes more ill-looking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:129
verses.text: But diseases and pains produce low spirits; and diseases are produced from the body too delicate through great luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:130
verses.text: So that even for this you will flee luxury, if you take my advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:131
verses.text: 'But, you will say, luxury gives pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:132
verses.text: ' Yes, but not so great as the annoyances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:133
verses.text: And besides, the pleasure goes no further than the palate and the tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:134
verses.text: For when the table has been removed, and the food swallowed, thou wilt be like one that has not partaken, or rather much worse, in that thou bearest thence oppression, and distension, and headache, and a sleep like death, and often too, sleeplessness from repletion, and obstruction of the breathing, and eructation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:135
verses.text: And thou wouldest curse bitterly thy belly, when thou oughtest to curse thy immoderate eating.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:136
verses.text: Let us not then fatten the body, but listen to Paul saying, "Make not provision for the flesh, to fulfill the lusts thereof," ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:137
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:138
verses.text: ) As if one should take food and throw it into a drain, so is he who throws it into the belly: or rather it is not so, but much worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:139
verses.text: For in the one case he uses the drain without harm to himself: but in the other he generates innumerable diseases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:140
verses.text: For what nourishes is a sufficiency which also can be digested: but what is over and above our need, not only does not nourish, but even spoils the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:141
verses.text: But no man sees these things, owing to some prejudice and unseasonable pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:142
verses.text: Dost thou wish to nourish the body? Take away what is superfluous; give what is sufficient, and as much as can be digested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:143
verses.text: Do not load it, lest thou overwhelm it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:144
verses.text: A sufficiency is both nourishment and pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:145
verses.text: For nothing is so productive of pleasure, as food well digested: nothing so [productive of] health: nothing [so productive of] acuteness of the faculties, nothing tends so much to keep away disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:146
verses.text: For a sufficiency is both nourishment, and pleasure, and health; but excess is injury, and unpleasantness and disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:147
verses.text: For what famine does, that also satiety does; or rather more grievous evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:148
verses.text: For the former indeed within a few days carries a man off and sets him free; but the other eating into and putrefying the body, gives it over to long disease, and then to a most painful death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:149
verses.text: But we, while we account famine a thing greatly to be dreaded, yet run after satiety, which is more distressing than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:150
verses.text: Whence is this disease? Whence this madness? I do not say that we should waste ourselves away, but that we should eat as much food as also gives us pleasure, that is really pleasure, and can nourish the body, and furnish it to us well ordered and adapted for the energies of the soul, well joined and fitted together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:151
verses.text: But when it comes to be water-logged by luxury, it cannot in the flood-wave, keep fast the bolts themselves, as one may say, and joints which hold the frame together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:152
verses.text: For the flood-wave coming in, the whole breaks up and scatters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:153
verses.text: "Make not provision for the flesh" (he says) "to fulfill the lusts thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:154
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:155
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:156
verses.text: ) He said well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:157
verses.text: For luxury is fuel for unreasonable lusts; though the luxurious should be the most philosophical of all men, of necessity he must be somewhat affected by wine, by eating, he must needs be relaxed, he must needs endure the greater flame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:158
verses.text: Hence [come] fornications, hence adulteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:159
verses.text: For a hungry belly cannot generate lust, or rather not one which has used just enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:160
verses.text: But that which generates unseemly lusts, is that which is relaxed by luxury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:161
verses.text: And as land which is very moist and a dung-hill which is wet through and retains much dampness, generates worms, while that which has been freed from such moistness bears abundant fruits, when it has nothing immoderate: even if it be not cultivated, it yields grass, and if it be cultivated, fruits: [so also do we].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:162
verses.text: Let us not then make our flesh useless, or unprofitable, or hurtful, but let us plant in it useful fruits, and fruit-bearing trees; let us not enfeeble them by luxury, for they too put forth worms instead of fruit when they are become rotten.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:163
verses.text: So also implanted desire, if thou moisten it above measure, generates unreasonable pleasures, yea the most exceedingly unreasonable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 30:164
verses.text: Let us then remove this pernicious evil, that we may be able to attain the good things promised us, in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory now and ever and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:1
verses.text: Homily XXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:2
verses.text: Hebrews xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:3
verses.text: –  "No chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous, nevertheless, afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:4
verses.text: Wherefore lift up the hands which hang down, and the feeble knees: and make straight paths for your feet, lest that which is lame be turned out of the way, but let it rather be healed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:5
verses.text: They who drink bitter medicines, first submit to some unpleasantness, and afterwards feel the benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:6
verses.text: For such is virtue, such is vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:7
verses.text: In the latter there is first the pleasure, then the despondency: in the former first the despondency, and then the pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:8
verses.text: But there is no equality; for it is not the same, to be first grieved and afterwards pleased, and to be first pleased and afterwards grieved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:9
verses.text: How so? because in the latter case the expectation of coming despondency makes the present pleasure less: but in the former the expectation of coming pleasure cuts away the violence of present despondency; so that the result is that in the one instance we never have pleasure, in the latter we never have grief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:10
verses.text: And the difference does not lie in this only, but also in other ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:11
verses.text: As how? That the duration is not equal, but far greater and more ample.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:12
verses.text: And here too, it is still more so in things spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:13
verses.text: From this [consideration] then Paul undertakes to console them; and again takes up the common judgment of men, which no one is able to stand against, nor to contend with the common decision, when one says what is acknowledged by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:14
verses.text: Ye are suffering, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:15
verses.text: For such is chastisement; such is its beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:16
verses.text: For "no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous but grievous".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:17
verses.text: Well said he, "seemeth not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:18
verses.text: Chastisement he means is not grievous but "seemeth" so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:19
verses.text: "All chastisement": not this and that, but "all," both human and spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:20
verses.text: Seest thou that he argues from our common notions? "Seemeth" (he says) "to be grievous," so that it is not [really so].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:21
verses.text: For what sort of grief brings forth joy? So neither does pleasure bring forth despondency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:22
verses.text: "Nevertheless, afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruits of righteousness to them which have been exercised thereby".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:23
verses.text: Not "fruit" but "fruits," a great abundance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:24
verses.text: "To them" (he says) "which have been exercised thereby".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:25
verses.text: What is "to them which have been exercised thereby"? To them that have endured for a long while, and been patient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:26
verses.text: And he uses an auspicious expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:27
verses.text: So then, chastisement is exercise, making the athlete strong, and invincible in combats, irresistible in wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:28
verses.text: If then "all chastisement" be such, this also will be such: so that we ought to look for good things, and for a sweet and peaceful end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:29
verses.text: And do not wonder if, being itself hard, it has sweet fruits; since in trees also the bark is almost destitute of all quality, and rough; but the fruits are sweet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:30
verses.text: But he took it from the common notion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:31
verses.text: If therefore we ought to look for such things, why do ye vex yourselves? Why, after ye have endured the painful, do ye despond as to the good? The distasteful things which ye had to endure, ye endured: do not then despond as to the recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:32
verses.text: He speaks as to runners, and boxers, and warriors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:33
verses.text: Seest thou how he arms them, how he encourages them? "Walk straight," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:34
verses.text: Here he speaks with reference to their thoughts; that is to say, not doubting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:35
verses.text: For if the chastisement be of love, if it begin from loving care, if it end with a good result (and this he proves both by facts and by words, and by all considerations), why are ye dispirited? For such are they who despair, who are not strengthened by the hope of the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:36
verses.text: "Walk straight," he says, that your lameness may not be increased, but brought back to its former condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:37
verses.text: For he that runs when he is lame, galls the sore place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:38
verses.text: Seest thou that it is in our power to be thoroughly healed?   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:39
verses.text: "Follow peace with all men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:40
verses.text: What he also said above, "Not forsaking the assembling of yourselves together" ( c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:41
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:42
verses.text: ), he hints at in this place also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:43
verses.text: For nothing so especially makes persons easily vanquished and subdued in temptations, as isolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:44
verses.text: For, tell me, scatter a phalanx in war, and the enemy will need no trouble, but will take them prisoners, coming on them separately, and thereby the more helpless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:45
verses.text: "Follow peace with all men, and holiness" (he says).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:46
verses.text: Therefore with the evil-doers as well? "If it be possible," he says, "as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:47
verses.text: ( Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:48
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:49
verses.text: ) For thy part (he means) "live peaceably," doing no harm to religion: but in whatever thou art ill-treated, bear it nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:50
verses.text: For the bearing with evil is a great weapon in trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:51
verses.text: Thus Christ also made His disciples strong by saying, "Behold I send you forth as sheep in the midst of wolves: be ye therefore wise as serpents, and harmless as doves," ( Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:52
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:53
verses.text: ) What dost Thou say? Are we "among wolves," and dost Thou bid us to be "as sheep," and "as doves"? Yea, He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:54
verses.text: For nothing so shames him that is doing us evil, as bearing nobly the things which are brought upon us: and not avenging ourselves either by word or by deed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:55
verses.text: This both makes us more philosophical ourselves and procures a greater reward, and also benefits them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:56
verses.text: But has such an one been insolent? Do thou bless [him].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:57
verses.text: See how much thou wilt gain from this: thou hast quenched the evil, thou hast procured to thyself a reward, thou hast made him ashamed, and thou hast suffered nothing serious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:58
verses.text: "Follow peace with all men, and holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:59
verses.text: What does he mean by "holiness" ? Chaste, and orderly living in marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:60
verses.text: If any person is unmarried (he says) let him remain pure, let him marry: or if he be married, let him not commit fornication, but let him live with his own wife: for this also is "holiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:61
verses.text: How? Marriage is not "holiness," but marriage preserves the holiness which [proceeds] from Faith, not permitting union with a harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:62
verses.text: For "marriage is honorable" ( c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:63
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:64
verses.text: ), not holy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:65
verses.text: Marriage is pure: it does not however also give holiness, except by forbidding the defilement of that [holiness] which has been given by our Faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:66
verses.text: "Without which" (he says) "no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:67
verses.text: Which he also says in the [Epistle] to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:68
verses.text: "Be not deceived: neither fornicators, nor adulterers, nor idolaters, nor effeminate, nor abusers of themselves with mankind, nor covetous persons, nor thieves, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners, shall inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:69
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:70
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:72
verses.text: ) For how shall he who has become the body of a harlot, how shall he be able to be the body of Christ?   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:73
verses.text: "Looking diligently lest any man come short of the grace of God; lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you, and thereby many be defiled: lest there be any fornicator or profane person".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:74
verses.text: Dost thou see how everywhere he puts the common salvation into the hands of each individual? "Exhorting one another daily" (he says) "while it is called To-day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:76
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:77
verses.text: ) Do not then cast all [the burden] on your teachers; do not [cast] all upon them who have the rule over you: ye also (he means) are able to edify one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:78
verses.text: Which also he said in writing to the Thessalonians, "Edify one another, even as also ye do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:79
verses.text: (  Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:80
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:81
verses.text: ) And again, "Comfort one another with these words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:82
verses.text: (  Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:83
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:84
verses.text: ) This we also now exhort you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:85
verses.text: If ye be willing, ye will have more success with each other than we can have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:86
verses.text: For ye both are with one another for a longer time, and ye know more than we of each other's affairs, and ye are not ignorant of each other's failings, and ye have more freedom of speech, and love, and intimacy; and these are no small [advantages] for teaching, but great and opportune introductions for it: ye will be more able than we both to reprove and to exhort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:87
verses.text: And not this only, but because I am but one, whereas ye are many; and ye will be able, however many, to be teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:88
verses.text: Wherefore I entreat you, do not "neglect this gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:89
verses.text: (  Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:90
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:91
verses.text: ) Each one of you has a wife, has a friend, has a servant, has a neighbor; let him reprove him, let him exhort him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:92
verses.text: For how is it not absurd, with regard to [bodily] nourishment, to make associations for messing together, and for drinking together, and to have a set day whereon to club with one another, as they say, and to make up by the association what each person being alone by himself fails short of—as for instance, if it be necessary to go to a funeral, or to a dinner, or to assist a neighbor in any matter—and not to do this for the purpose of instruction in virtue? Yea, I entreat you, let no man neglect it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:93
verses.text: For great is the reward he receives from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:94
verses.text: And that thou mayest understand, he who was entrusted with the five talents is the teacher: and he with the one is the learner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:95
verses.text: If the learner should say, I am a learner, I run no risk, and should hide the reason, which he received of God, that common and simple [reason], and give no advice, should not speak plainly, should not rebuke, should not admonish, if he is able, but should bury [his talents] in the earth (for truly that heart is earth and ashes, which hides the gift of God): if then he hides it either from indolence, or from wickedness, it will be no defense to him to say, 'I had but one talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:96
verses.text: ' Thou hadst one talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:97
verses.text: Thou oughtest then to have brought one besides, and to have doubled the talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:98
verses.text: If thou hadst brought one in addition, thou wouldst not have been blamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:99
verses.text: For neither did He say to him who brought the two, Wherefore hast thou not brought five? But He accounted him of the same worth with him who brought the five.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:100
verses.text: Why? Because he gained as much as he had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:101
verses.text: And, because he had received fewer than the one entrusted with the five, he was not on this account negligent, nor did he use the smallness [of his trust, as an excuse] for idleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:102
verses.text: And thou oughtest not to have looked to him who had the two; or rather, thou oughtest to have looked to him, and as he having two imitated him who had five, so oughtest thou to have emulated him who had two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:103
verses.text: For if for him who has means and does not give, there is punishment, how shall there not be the greatest punishment for him who is able to exhort in any way, and does it not? In the former case the body is nourished, in the latter the soul; there thou preventest temporal death, here eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:104
verses.text: But I have no [skill of] speech, you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:105
verses.text: But there is no need of [skill of] speech nor of eloquence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:106
verses.text: If thou see a friend going into fornication, say to him, Thou art going after an evil thing; art thou not ashamed? Dost thou not blush? This is wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:107
verses.text: 'Why, does he not know' (you say) 'that it is wrong?' Yes, but he is dragged on by lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:108
verses.text: They that are sick also know that it is bad to drink cold water, nevertheless they need persons who shall hinder [them from it].

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:109
verses.text: For he who is suffering, will not easily be able to help himself in his sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:110
verses.text: There is need therefore of thee who art in health, for his cure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:111
verses.text: And if he be not persuaded by thy words, watch for him as he goes away and hold him fast; peradventure he will be ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:112
verses.text: 'And what advantage is it' (you say), 'when he does this for my sake, and because he has been held back by me?' Do not be too minute in thy calculations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:113
verses.text: For a while, by whatever means, withdraw him from his evil practice; let him be accustomed not to go off to that pit, whether through thee, or through any means whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:114
verses.text: When thou hast accustomed him not to go, then by taking him after he has gained breath a little thou wilt be able to teach him that he ought to do this for God's sake, and not for man's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:115
verses.text: Do not wish to make all right at once, since you cannot: but do it gently and by degrees.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:116
verses.text: If thou see him going off to drinking, or to parties where there is nothing but drunkenness, then also do the same; and again on the other hand intreat him, if he observe that thou hast any failing, to help thee and set thee right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:117
verses.text: For in this way, he will even of himself, bear reproof, when he sees both that thou needest reproofs as well, and that thou helpest him, not as one that had done everything right, nor as a teacher, but as a friend and a brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:118
verses.text: Say to him, I have done thee a service, in reminding thee of things expedient: do thou also, whatever failing thou seest me have, hold me back, set me right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:119
verses.text: If thou see me irritable, if avaricious, restrain me, bind me by exhortation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:120
verses.text: This is friendship; thus "brother aided by brother becomes a fortified city".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:121
verses.text: ( Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:122
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:123
verses.text: ) For not eating and drinking makes friendship: such friendship even robbers have and murderers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:124
verses.text: But if we are friends, if we truly care for one another, let us in these respects help one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:125
verses.text: This leads us to a profitable friendship: let us hinder those things which lead away to hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:126
verses.text: Therefore let not him that is reproved be indignant: for we are men and we have failings; neither let him who reproves do it as exulting over him and making a display, but privately, with gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:127
verses.text: He that reproves has need of greater gentleness, that thus he may persuade [them] to bear the cutting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:128
verses.text: Do you not see surgeons, when they burn, when they cut, with how great gentleness they apply their treatment? Much more ought those who reprove others to act thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:129
verses.text: For reproof is sharper even than fire and knife, and makes [men] start.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:130
verses.text: On this account surgeons take great pains to make them bear the cutting quietly, and apply it as tenderly as possible, even giving in a little, then giving time to take breath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:131
verses.text: So ought we also to offer reproofs, that the reproved may not start away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:132
verses.text: Even if therefore, it be necessary to be insulted, yea even to be struck, let us not decline it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:133
verses.text: For those also who are cut [by the surgeons] utter numberless cries against those who are cutting them; they however heed none of these things, but only the health of the patients.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:134
verses.text: So indeed in this case also we ought to do all things that our reproof may be effectual, to bear all things, looking to the reward which is in store.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:135
verses.text: "Bear ye one another's burdens," saith he, "and so fulfill the law of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:136
verses.text: ( Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:137
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:138
verses.text: ) So then, both reproving and bearing with one another, shall we be able to fulfill edification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:139
verses.text: And thus will ye make the labor light for us, in all things taking a part with us, and stretching out a hand, and becoming sharers and partakers, both in one another's salvation, and each one in his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 31:140
verses.text: Let us then endure patiently, both bearing "one another's burdens," and reproving: that we may attain to the good things promised in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:1
verses.text: Homily XXXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:2
verses.text: Hebrews xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:3
verses.text: "Follow peace with all men, and holiness, without which no one shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:4
verses.text: There are many things characteristic of Christianity: but more than all, and better than all, Love towards one another, and Peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:5
verses.text: Therefore Christ also saith, "My peace I give unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:6
verses.text: ( John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:7
verses.text: ) And again, "By this shall all men know that ye are My disciples, if ye love one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:8
verses.text: ( John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:9
verses.text: ) Therefore Paul too says, "Follow peace with all men, and holiness," that is, purity, "without which no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:10
verses.text: "Looking diligently lest any man fail of the grace of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:11
verses.text: As if they were traveling together on some long journey, in a large company, he says, Take heed that no man be left behind: I do not seek this only, that ye should arrive yourselves, but also that ye should look diligently after the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:12
verses.text: "Lest any man" (he says) "fail of the grace of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:13
verses.text: (He means the good things to come, the faith of the gospel, the best course of life: for they all are of "the Grace of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:14
verses.text: ) Do not tell me, It is [but] one that perisheth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:15
verses.text: Even for one Christ died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:16
verses.text: Hast thou no care for him "for whom Christ died"? (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:17
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:18
verses.text: )  "Looking diligently," he saith, that is, searching carefully, considering, thoroughly ascertaining, as is done in the case of sick persons, and in all ways examining, thoroughly ascertaining.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:19
verses.text: "Lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:20
verses.text: ( Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:21
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:22
verses.text: ) This is found in Deuteronomy; and he derived it from the metaphor of plants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:23
verses.text: "Lest any root of bitterness," he says; which he said also in another place when he writes, "A little leaven leaveneth the whole lump".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:24
verses.text: (  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:25
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:26
verses.text: ) Not for his sake alone do I wish this, he means, but also on account of the harm arising therefrom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:27
verses.text: That is to say, even if there be a root of this kind, do not suffer any shoot to come up, but let it be cut off, that it may not bear its proper fruits, that so it may not defile and pollute the others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:28
verses.text: For, he saith, "Lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you; and by it many be defiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:29
verses.text: And with good reason did he call sin "bitter": for truly nothing is more bitter than sin, and they know it, who after they have committed it pine away under their conscience, who endure much bitterness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:30
verses.text: For being exceedingly bitter, it perverts the reasoning faculty itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:31
verses.text: Such is the nature of what is bitter: it is unprofitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:32
verses.text: And well said he, "root of bitterness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:33
verses.text: He said not, "bitter," but "of bitterness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:34
verses.text: For it is possible that a bitter root might bear sweet fruits; but it is not possible that a root and fountain and foundation of bitterness, should ever bear sweet fruit; for all is bitter, it has nothing sweet, all are bitter, all unpleasant, all full of hatred and abomination.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:35
verses.text: "And by this" (he says) "many be defiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:36
verses.text: That is, Cut off the lascivious persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:37
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:38
verses.text: "Lest there be any fornicator: or profane person, as Esau, who for one morsel of meat sold his birthright".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:39
verses.text: And wherein was Esau a "fornicator"? He does not say that Esau was a fornicator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Hebrews 32:40
